HEjFjYEg.title: Hydrogenolysis of glycerol over homogenously dispersed copper on solid base catalysts
HEjFjYEg.abstract: Graphical abstract Research highlights ▶ Homogenously dispersed copper on layered solid base catalyst was synthesized. ▶ The dispersion of Cu was characterized by TEM, N 2 O adsorption and in-situ XRD. ▶ This catalyst is extremely effective for hydrogenolysis of glycerol at 180 °C. ▶ The conversion of glycerol depends strongly on the particle size of copper. ▶ Solid base can suppress the cleavage of C–C bond in glycerol. Abstract Homogenously dispersed copper on layered solid base (Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP, with 80.1% dispersion of copper) was synthesized via thermal decomposition of the as-synthesized Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 layered double hydroxides. This bi-functional highly dispersed Cu-solid base catalyst is extremely effective for hydrogenolysis of aqueous glycerol. The detected conversion of glycerol reached 80.0% with a 98.2% selectivity of 1,2-propanediol at 180 °C, 3.0 MPa H 2 and 20 h. But copper dispersed poorly in those catalysts prepared via impregnation and ion-exchange, and their activities were lower. These precursors and catalysts were characterized by N 2 -adsorption, X-ray diffraction, scanning electronic microscope, transmission electronic microscope, thermo-gravimetry, temperature-programmed reduction with H 2 , in-situ XRD, dissociative N 2 O adsorption and CO 2 temperature-programmed desorption. It was confirmed that the as-synthesized Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 showed a well crystallized layer-structure of hydrotalcite and copper dispersed homogenously on the layer-structure of hydrotalcite after thermal decomposition and H 2 reduction. Keywords Biodiesel Glycerol Hydrogenolysis Cu-solid base 1,2-Propanediol 1 Introduction Highly dispersed copper catalysts show good activity and selectivity in a series of reactions such as steam reforming [1–3] , hydrogenation [4–7] , ester hydrogenolysis [8] , reduction of NO x [9–11] , oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons [12,13] . A lot of methods were reported to prepare highly dispersed copper catalyst, of which the most common routines are impregnation and sol–gel. Whereas drawbacks such as inhomogeneous agglomeration of copper species at higher content resulting in large-sized particles in impregnation and lower activities due to encapsulation of active phase in some sol–gel catalysts were brought about [14] . Hydrotalcite-type compounds, also known as “anionic clays” have attracted much attention in recent years because of their potential applications in biodiesel synthesis [15,16] , environmental protection [17,18] , catalysts [19–21] , catalysts supports [22] and polymer additives [23] . Their empirical formula is [M II 1− x M III x (OH) 2 ] x + [A n − x / n ] x − · m H 2 O, where M II is a divalent metal such as Mg, Zn, Ni, Co or Cu, M III is a trivalent metal such as Al, Cr, Fe or Ga. A n − is an anion of charge n such as NO 3 − , Cl − , CO 3 2− and others, m is the molar amount of co-intercalated water. The values of x generally vary between 0.20 and 0.40 which determines the charge density of the positive layer and the anion exchange capacity [24] . The structure of these hydrotalcite-like compounds can be interpreted through comparing it to the brucite [Mg(OH) 2 ] lattice, in which magnesium cations (Mg 2+ ion) occupy the centers of hydroxide octahedra. In hydrotalcite-type compounds, partial Mg 2+ ion (M II ) is substituted by aluminum (Al 3+ ion) or other isomorphous trivalent cations, and the resulted net positive charge in cationic sheet is compensated by anions such as CO 3 2− , Cl − and OH − that present in the gallery between the brucite-like sheets [24,25] . The well-defined structure of hydrotalcite is shown in Fig. 1 . Herein, we report another method to obtain the highly dispersed copper catalyst through thermal decomposition of Cu/Mg/Al hydrotalcite-like compound. Homogenously dispersed copper catalysts with a large surface area, strong basic properties and high stability against sintering can be obtained through controlling the decomposition of the hydrotalcite-like precursors. Glycerol, as a byproduct, is produced in large amounts in the production of biodiesel via transesterification of triglycerides with methanol in the presence of basic or acidic catalysts. Finding out new outlets to make good use of this surplus glycerol can accelerate the development of biodiesel. Up to now, many efforts have been put toward the conversion of glycerol to more valuable chemicals such as propanediols [26,27] , glyceric acid [28–31] and glycols. Among of which, converting glycerol to 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) by selective catalytic hydrogenolysis ( Scheme 1 ) has attracted much attention in recent years [32–38] . Over hybrid Ru/C (or Rh/SiO 2 ) + solid acids [35–37] and ruthenium-doped acidic heteropoly salt Cs 2.5 H 0.5 [PW 12 O 40 ] [32] catalysts, glycerol hydrogenolysis performs in dehydration of glycerol to acetol (on acid sites) and followed by acetol hydrogenation to 1,2-PDO (on the metal particles). But the conversion of glycerol was low and mainly noble metals were reported. In basic solutions, glycerol could dehydrogenate to glyceraldehydes in first, followed by dehydration to 2-hydroxyacrolein and then hydrogenate to 1,2-PDO over Pt/C and Ru/C catalysts [39–43] . But the added alkali such as NaOH in glycerol hydrogenolysis system caused the cleavage of C–C bond. According to the mechanisms of the glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-PDO, a solid bi-functional catalyst consisting of metal and acidic/basic sites should be capable for this reaction. Choosing solid base and/or solid acid as a component and support of metal catalyst would be an alternative of the hybrid catalysts. In our previous works, hydrotalcite, MgO, Al 2 O 3 , H-ZSM5 and H-Beta supported Pt catalysts were tested for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO. And it was found that solid base (such as hydrotalcite and MgO) supported Pt catalysts exhibited the predominant activity and higher 1,2-PDO selectivity than that of solid acids (Al 2 O 3 , H-ZSM5 and H-Beta) [44] . More recently, we found that MgO supported copper is also an efficient catalyst for glycerol hydrogenolysis with high selectivity of 1,2-PDO [45] . In present work, we want to report a homogenously dispersed Cu on solid base catalyst prepared via thermal decomposition of layered double hydroxides of Cu x Mg 6− x Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 , and this bi-functional catalyst was used in glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-PDO. These catalysts were characterized by N 2 -adsorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), thermogravimetry-differential scanning calorimetry (TG-DSC), in-situ XRD, temperature-programmed reduction with H 2 (H 2 -TPR), dissociative N 2 O adsorption and CO 2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD). The relation between the performance for hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO and the structure of the catalysts were discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Three hydrotalcite-like compounds with Cu:Mg:Al molar ratios of 0.4:5.6:2, 0.8:5.2:2 and 1.5:4.5:2 were prepared by coprecipitation. Required amounts of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 ·3H 2 O, Al(NO 3 ) 3 ·9H 2 O and Mg(NO 3 ) 2 ·6H 2 O (Shanghai Chemicals, China, AR) were dissolved in 400 mL distilled water under stirring, and this solution was referred as A, in which Al 3+ /(Cu 2+ + Mg 2+ + Al 3+ ) = 0.25 and (Cu 2+ + Mg 2+ + Al 3+ ) = 0.2 mol/L. Solution B was an aqueous of NaOH and Na 2 CO 3 , in which the concentration of Na 2 CO 3 and NaOH are 0.25 and 0.8 mol/L, respectively. Then solution A and solution B were added slowly (in around 2 h) to a 2 L breaker under vigorously stirring at room temperature, the pH was maintained at 9.5 during dripping process. The resulted suspension was transferred to a 1 L round-bottom flask and processed in circumfluence at 110 °C for 12 h, filtered off and washed thoroughly with distilled water until the pH of filtrate reached 7.0. Precipitate was then dried at 80 °C for 12 h followed by calcination at 300 °C for 4 h. Catalysts prepared according to this method were identified as Cu x Mg 6− x Al 2 O 9 -CP, x referred the amount of Cu 2+ . After hydrogen reduction at 300 °C for 1 h, these catalysts were identified as Cu x /Mg 6− x Al 2 O 9− x -CP. Mg–Al hydrotalcite supported copper catalysts were also prepared by impregnation and ion-exchange, and compared as references. Mg 6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 hydrotalcite (Shanghai Chemicals, China, AR) was firstly pretreated at 60 °C in vacuum for 12 h, and impregnated in an aqueous solution of Cu(NO 3 ) 2 ·3H 2 O for 4 h. Then the precursor was treated in ambient air at 80 °C overnight followed by calcination at 300 °C for 4 h. Catalyst prepared in this method was identified as Cu–Mg–Al-IM, in which Cu:Mg:Al molar ratio was controlled as 0.4:5.6:2. Required amounts of pretreated Mg 6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 hydrotalcite were added into an aqueous solution of CuCl 2 ·2H 2 O, ion-exchanged in circumfluence at 50 °C for 24 h under vigorously stirring. Then the suspension was washed with distilled water thoroughly and treated in ambient air at 80 °C overnight followed by calcination at 300 °C for 4 h. Catalyst prepared in this method was identified as Cu–Mg–Al-IE, in which Cu:Mg:Al molar ratio was controlled as 0.4:5.6:2. 2.2 Characterizations Element chemical analysis of Cu, Mg and Al was carried out by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP, Plasma-Spec-II spectrometer), and actual amount of these metals in prepared catalysts were confirmed and summarized in Table 1 . N 2 adsorption was measured at its normal boiling point (−196 °C) using an ASAP 2010 analyzer (Micromeritics) after samples were pretreated at 250 °C for 4 h in vacuum. BET surface area and pore structure were calculated on adsorption branch. XRD patterns were collected on a Rigaku D/MAX-2500 diffractometer in a 2 θ range of 5–70° using Cu K α radiation ( λ = 1.5406 Å). The particle sizes of CuO and Cu were estimated by using Scherrer equation. In-situ XRD in a 10% H 2 /Ar flow (30 mL/min) was carried out on the same system connected to an Anton-Paar high-temperature XRK assembly in which sample was mounted in a high-temperature cell, heated at 10 °C/min, and stabilized for 5 min before measurements. TG-DSC was carried out on a Netzsch STA 409 thermo-balance. Analysis was done from 30 to 530 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen (30 mL/min). SEM images of these hydrotalcite-like samples were taken on a microscope (Leo Series VP 1430, Germany) having silicon detector equipped with energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) facility (Oxford instruments). Samples were coated with gold using sputter coating to avoid charging. Analysis was carried out at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV. TEM images of reduced catalysts were recorded using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV (JEOL-2010 F). Before TEM analysis, catalysts were reduced in a stream of H 2 at 300 °C for 1 h, the reduced powders were poured into alcohol under the protection of H 2 and suspended with an ultrasonic dispersion for 10 min, and then the resulted solution was dropped on carbon film of nickel grid. TPR experiments were conducted on a quartz reactor. Samples were first loaded and pretreated at 350 °C for 1 h under N 2 flow (30 mL/min). After sample was cooled to room temperature, reduction agent (10% H 2 /N 2 mixture, 30 mL/min) was shifted; sample was heated to 350 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. Effluent gas was dried by powder KOH and consumption of hydrogen was analyzed by thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The amounts of hydrogen consumption were calibrated using known amounts of CuO. The number of surface metallic copper sites was determined by dissociative N 2 O adsorption at 50 °C using the procedure described by Van Der Grift et al. [46] . Catalysts were first reduced in the procedure described in above TPR experiment in 10% H 2 /N 2 mixture (30 mL/min) until 350 °C. The amount of hydrogen consumption in first TPR was denoted as X . And then, the catalyst bed was purged with He and cooled to 50 °C. Surface copper atoms were oxidized in a 20% N 2 O/N 2 (30 mL/min) at 50 °C for 0.5 h. Finally, samples were flushed with He to remove the oxidant and cooled to room temperature to start another TPR run. Hydrogen consumption in the second TPR was denoted as Y . The dispersion of Cu and exposed Cu surface area are calculated on the equations reported by Van Der Grift et al. [46a] , repeat: All copper atoms were reduced in the first TPR: CuO + H 2 → Cu + H 2 O, hydrogen consumption = X Surface copper atoms that were oxidized to Cu 2 O by N 2 O at 50 °C were reduced in the second TPR: Cu 2 O + H 2 → 2Cu + H 2 O, hydrogen consumption = Y And the dispersion of Cu and exposed Cu surface area were calculated as: D = ( 2 × Y / X ) × 100 % S = 2 × Y × N av / ( X × M Cu × 1.4 × 10 19 ) = 1353 × Y / X ( m 2 -Cu / g-Cu ) where N av = Avogadro's constant, M Cu = relative atomic mass (63.456 g/mol), 1.4 × 10 19 comes from that an equal abundance of an average copper surface atom area of 0.0711 nm 2 (equivalent to 1.4 × 10 19 copper atoms per square meter). The alkalinity of Cu x Mg 6− x Al 2 O 9 -CP catalysts were carried out via temperature-programmed desorption of CO 2 . Sample was first reduced at 300 °C in H 2 flow of 30 mL/min for 1 h, and then cooled to 100 °C in purified Ar, exposed to 50% CO 2 /Ar for 30 min, purged by Ar for 5 h at 100 °C in order to eliminate the physical adsorbed CO 2 . Temperature-programmed desorption was conducted by ramping to 550 °C at 10 °C/min and CO 2 ( m / e = 44) in effluent was detected and recorded as a function of temperature by a quadrupole mass spectrometer (OmniStarTM, GSD301, Switzerland). 2.3 Catalytic reactions The discontinuous glycerol reaction was carried out in a custom-designed 50-mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a thermoelectric couple. Unless specifically stated, all samples were pre-reduced in a stream of H 2 at 300 °C for 1 h before they were used for catalytic hydrogenolysis of glycerol. Aqueous solution of glycerol (8.0 mL, 75 wt%) and 1.0 g reduced catalyst were added to the reactor. The autoclave was purged with H 2 to 3.0 MPa and placed in an oil bath preheated to required temperature and maintained at that temperature for a given period time under vigorously stirring with a magnetic stirrer (MAG-NEO, RV-06 M, Japan). Reactant solution was cooled to room temperature after reaction and vapor phase was collected by a gas-bag and analyzed using a TCD gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 8A) equipped with an active carbon column. Liquid phase was centrifuged to remove solid catalyst powder and analyzed using a FID gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, 14 B) equipped with a 30 m capillary column (DB-WAX 52 CB, USA). All products detected in the liquid phase and gas phase were quantified via external calibration method. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 N 2 -adsorption Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP, Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 9 -CP and Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 9 -CP are shown in Fig. 2 . All of them are type II according to the IUPAC classification, while the location of hysteresis loop shifted to higher pressure with increasing of Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ . These results inferred that there is a large amount of slit-slapped pore channels formed because of aggregation of plate-like layers. The closure points of hysteresis loops occurred at a relative pressure of 0.48 in Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP and Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 9 -CP, suggesting that they have similar pore architecture. But the closure points of loop of Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 9 -CP increased to a relative pressure of 0.68, which inferred that the pore diameter increased. BET surface area, pore volume and average pore size of Cu x Mg 6− x Al 2 O 9 -CP samples (calculated from their adsorption isotherms) are summarized in Table 2 . It can be seen that the calculated surface area and pore volume of Cu x Mg 6− x Al 2 O 9 -CP decreased slightly with increasing Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ ratio, whereas average pore diameter increased. This could be contributed to the orderliness of crystallites decreased with increasing of copper content. 3.2 XRD XRD patterns of as-synthesized Cu x Mg 6− x Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 hydrotalcite are shown in Fig. 3 . Sharp and symmetrical reflections at 11.7°, 23.2°, 60.6° and 61.8° were detected in all samples, which are ascribed to diffraction of (0 0 3), (0 0 6), (1 1 0) and (1 1 3) planes in layered structure. Broad and asymmetric reflections at 34.7°, 38.8° and 46.0° were also appeared due to the diffraction of (1 0 2), (1 0 5) and (1 0 8) planes. All characteristic reflection peaks of a well-crystallized hydrotalcite (JCPDS 41-1428) were detected, indicating that Mg 2+ ion in brucite-like layers are replaced by Cu 2+ ion, which can be attributed to the similar ionic radii of Cu 2+ ion (0.73 Å) and Mg 2+ ion (0.72 Å) [47] . It can be seen that the intensity and sharpness of (1 1 0) and (1 1 3) reflections decrease with increasing Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ ratio, which means the orderliness of the crystallite decreases in the hydrotalcite with higher copper content. Chemical composition and structural characteristics of these samples are summarized in Table 1 . The detected composition of as-synthesized samples are close to that of starting mixed aqueous solutions within experimental errors, suggesting that all cations in hydrotalcite structure are approximately completely incorporated. Lattice parameters a (cation–cation distance in brucite-like layer) and c = 3 c ′ ( c ′ is the thickness of one brucite-like layer and one interlayer) were calculated from the (0 0 3), (0 0 6) and (1 1 0) reflections on base of the rhombohedral symmetry of hydrotalcite and are summarized in Table 1 . The calculated a is nearly the same in all samples in this work, and this value is quite close to that of Mg–Al hydrotalcite published in reference [48] , indicating Mg 2+ ion were substituted by Cu 2+ ion isomorphously in brucite layers. Because the width of brucite-like layers is 4.8 Å [49] , the interlayer distance is close to 2.9-3.0 Å, which is can be calculated from c = 3 c ′. And these data inferred that the location of carbonate anions with their molecular planes parallels to the brucite-like layers ( Fig. 1 ). After calcination, the characteristic lamellar structure of Cu–Mg–Al hydrotalcite still remained in Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP, whereas the framework collapsed partially in Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 9 -CP and disappeared completely in Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 9 -CP. CuO (JCPDS 48-1548) and Cu(OH) 2 (JCPDS 42-0638) were detected in calcined Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 9 -CP ( Fig. 4 ). These results mean that the lamellar structure with lower Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ is more stable. This higher thermal stability of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP could protect the homogenous dispersion of Cu. Inter-planar spacing calculated from the (0 0 3) reflection decreased in calcined Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 9 -CP, and the range of lamellar structure becomes out-of-order after calcination, both of which can be ascribed to partially loss of carbonate and water in the gallery of hydrotalcite during calcination. Lamellar structure in Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 9 -CP collapsed completely after calcination, which lead to sintering of CuO to bigger particles. The framework collapsed in samples with higher Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ ratio might be explained by Jahn–Teller distortion which brings about the poor long rang ordering [50] . Fig. 5 compared the XRD patterns of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 , Cu–Mg–Al-IE and Cu–Mg–Al-IM that have the same Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ /Al 3+ ratio (Cu/Mg/Al = 0.4/5.6/2). It can be found that Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 possesses perfect characteristic lamellar structure of hydrotalcite. Cu–Mg–Al-IE also shows characteristic lamellar structure of hydrotalcite, but separated Cu 2+ ions (that just adsorbed on the surface of hydrotalcite) were detected at 16.3° and 18.2°. Another unwanted phase detected at 31.2° can be ascribed to Mg 2+ resorted on the surface of hydrotalcite and contacted with Cl − and OH − . Cu–Mg–Al-IM shows characteristic of hydrotalcite with most of Cu 2+ adsorbed on the surface of hydrotalcite. In other words, rarely Cu 2+ ions can insert into the structure of hydrotalcite by impregnation. These results can be summarized in that Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 prepared by coprecipitation exhibited the most perfect structure of hydrotalcite with all Cu 2+ dispersed homogenously in the matrix. But Cu/Mg/Al catalysts prepared via ion-exchange and impregnation showed poor lamellar structure and only part amount of Cu 2+ can substitute Mg 2+ . 3.3 TG-DSC Fig. 6 shows the TG-DSC profiles of as synthesized Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 . TG profile indicates two major weight losses at around 135–220 °C and 330–430 °C, which can be identified as the losses of adsorbed surface water bound to gallery or external surfaces and H-bound water in interlayer [51] . The overall weight loss from 30 °C to 530 °C is 36.4%, which is conformed with the formula of as-synthesize Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 and calcined Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 . 3.4 SEM analysis Fig. 7 (a)–(c) shows micrographs of as-synthesized Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 , Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 and Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 , respectively. The images of separated particles of these samples are shown as insert. It can be clearly seen that single particle appears a shape of ball-flower sized in 1.5–2.5 μm. Under high-resolution, well developed layered and platelet structure could be identified, and the inter-particle space formed by accumulating of platelets became larger with increased copper content, which is consisted with those results detected in N 2 -adsorption (as shown in Table 2 ). And this inter-particle space can be considered as the source of mesopores. The average thickness of platelets in Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 , Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 and Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 are 20, 30 and 40 nm, respectively. Fig. 7 (d) and (e) shows micrographs of Cu–Mg–Al-IM and Cu–Mg–Al-IE. Both of them showed indistinct morphologies of layered and platelet structure, which indicated that lamellar structure partially collapsed during catalyst preparation. 3.5 TEM analysis Fig. 8 shows TEM images of reduced Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP, Cu–Mg–Al-IE and Cu–Mg–Al-IM that has the same Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ /Al 3+ ratio (Cu/Mg/Al = 0.4/5.6/2). Fig. 8 (a) shows the cross-section of layered platelet in reduced Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP, from which it can be found that the gallery structure of hydrotalcite. The measured d spacing in reduced Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP is 0.8 nm, which fits well with that detected in XRD. No separated Cu particle can be identified, which inferred that copper dispersed homogenously in the matrix of hydrotalcite. On the other hand, a lot of separated copper particles sized in 10–20 and 25–40 nm were detected in typical TEM images of reduced Cu–Mg–Al-IE and Cu–Mg–Al-IM. High resolution TEM images of Cu–Mg–Al-IE and Cu–Mg–Al-IM found that Cu particles dispersed unevenly, and the average particle size of Cu detected in HRTEM (summarized in Table 3 ) was calculated as: d TEM = ∑ n i d i 3 ∑ n i d i 2 where n i is the number of particles having a characteristic diameter d i . The calculated copper particle sizes in Cu–Mg–Al-IE and Cu–Mg–Al-IM in their HRTEM images are 12.5 and 33.0 nm, respectively. 3.6 H 2 -TPR Fig. 9 illustrates H 2 -TPR profiles of calcined Cu/Mg/Al samples prepared by coprecipitation with different Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ . Only one broader peak from 150 to 260 °C was detected in Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP. This hydrogen consumption could be attributed to the reduction of Cu 2+ ions in lamellar structure of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP. But Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 9 -CP and Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 9 -CP have two hydrogen consumption peaks, indicating that different kinds of Cu species formed. The first detected peak in Cu 0.8 Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 9 -CP (at 170 °C) can be ascribed to the reduction of highly dispersed copper oxide species that existed on outside surface of lamellar and the second peak (at 205 °C) can be assigned as reduction of Cu 2+ ions in lamellar structure. And similarly, reduction peaks in Cu 1.5 Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 9 -CP can be ascribed to reduction of Cu 2+ ions in lamellar structure (at 205 °C) and bulk copper oxide particles that were embedded in lamellar structure (at 230 °C). Fig. 4 confirmed that characteristic lamellar structure in Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP remained after calcination and no separated CuO could be detected. In this suggestion, homogenously dispersed copper could be prepared via the reduction of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP. Fig. 10 compares the H 2 -TPR profiles of Cu/Mg/Al hydrotalcite samples prepared by different methods with same Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ /Al 3+ ratio (Cu/Mg/Al = 0.4/5.6/2). Both Cu–Mg–Al-IM and Cu–Mg–Al-IE exhibited two hydrogen consumption peaks. The first peak at 237 °C can be ascribed to reduction of bulk copper oxide particles that were embedded in lamellar structure and the second reduction peak at 312 °C is suggested to reduction of another CuO species with a strong interaction with the surface of Mg/Al mixed oxides [45] . 3.7 In-situ XRD of the catalyst reduction process Fig. 11 shows in-situ XRD spectra of H 2 reduction process of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP in a 10% H 2 /Ar flow (30 mL/min). The intensity of the basal reflections (0 0 3) decreased gradually and the relative angle shifted to higher position with increasing temperature, whereas the reflection (0 0 6) disappeared completely and the reflection (1 0 2) becomes broader. The peak at 43.5° was the reflection of Al 2 O 3 that is added to sample as reference. These changes in diffraction peaks can be ascribed to the disappearance of interlayer water molecules, and consequently shrinkage of interlayer space [47] . It is quite interesting to note that lamellar structure of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP remains stable in 10% H 2 /Ar flow below 280 °C. H 2 -TPR ( Fig. 9 ) has disclosed that Cu 2+ ions in lamellar structure of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP could be reduced completely from 150 to 260 °C, but no copper species could be detected in this in-situ reduction process. These results also indicated that copper species reduced from the lamellar structure of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP is homogenously dispersed in the matrix. 3.8 N 2 O adsorption Above XRD, SEM and TEM characterizations confirmed that a well-crystallized Cu x Mg 6− x Al 2 (OH) 16 CO 3 hydrotalcite could be synthesized when the added amount of Cu is lower ( x < 0.8), and the lamellar structure in these precursors is stable after calcination and reduction (see Fig. 8 – TEM image). Cu dispersed homogenously in the hydrotalcite precursor derived Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP lamellar, separated copper specie cannot be detected in XRD or TEM. Chemisorption of N 2 O experiments were carried out in order to identify the dispersion of copper. Fig. 12 shows the reduction profiles of Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP catalyst before and after N 2 O oxidation at 50 °C. According to the calculated hydrogen consumptions in the TPR of fresh Cu 0.4 Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 9 -CP (curve a ) and in the second TPR of freshly oxidized surface Cu 2 O phase after N 2 O oxidation (curve b ), copper dispersion and exposed copper area could be calculated by these equations reported by Van Der Grift et al. [46a] . These results are summarized in Table 3 . It can be found that the dispersion of copper in reduced Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP and Cu 0.8 /Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 8.2 -CP catalysts reached to 80.1% and 65.9%, respectively. In those catalysts with the same Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ /Al 3+ ratio (Cu/Mg/Al = 0.4/5.6/2), the calculated copper surface area in reduced Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP, Cu–Mg–Al-IE and Cu–Mg–Al-IM are 1083, 153 and 30 m 2 /g-Cu, respectively. These values are generally in agreement with that obtained in TEM images. 3.9 CO 2 -TPD CO 2 -TPD of Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP, Cu 0.8 /Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 8.2 -CP and Cu 1.5 /Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 7.5 -CP are shown in Fig. 13 . Because the physical adsorbed CO 2 was blown at 100 °C for 5 h, mainly one desorption peak at 245 °C was detected in Cu 1.5 /Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 7.5 -CP. A shoulder peak at 360 °C appeared in Cu 0.8 /Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 8.2 -CP, and this peak increased in Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP. These results indicated that both the amount and the strength of the alkalinity sites increased with the amount of Mg. 3.10 Glycerol hydrogenolysis The activity of these catalysts for hydrogenolysis of aqueous glycerol at 180 °C and 3.0 MPa H 2 are summarized in Table 4 . Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP catalyst exhibited the best activity for hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO, conversion of glycerol and selectivity of 1,2-PDO reached 80.0% and 98.2%, respectively. While conversion of glycerol decreased to 51.8% and 29.6% over Cu 0.8 /Mg 5.2 Al 2 O 8.2 -CP and Cu 1.5 /Mg 4.5 Al 2 O 7.5 -CP, because of sintering of copper particles during catalyst preparation. In those catalysts with the same Cu 2+ /Mg 2+ /Al 3+ ratio (Cu/Mg/Al = 0.4/5.6/2), Cu–Mg–Al-IM showed the lowest activity for hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO with a 22.6% glycerol conversion and a 95.3% selectivity of 1,2-PDO. The activity of Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP catalyst is higher than that of solid acids supported copper catalyst [38] , and MgO supported copper and Pt catalysts [44] , and is comparable with that of hybrid Ru/C (or Rh/SiO 2 )-Amberlyst [35,37,38] and Pt/C (or Ru/C)-NaOH [41,42] . And what is more interesting is that cleavage of C–C bond (catalyzed by NaOH in liquid phase) was suppressed efficiently. These results indicated that the conversion of glycerol depends strongly on the particle size of copper, smaller sized copper is extremely active and solid base can suppress the cleavage of C–C bond in glycerol. Unlike to that of Pt/C and Ru/C catalyst, small amount of NaOH further increased the activity of Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP without distinct loss of the selectivity of 1,2-PDO. As it is summarized in Table 4 , conversion of glycerol is further increased to 91.2% (with a 95.5% selectivity of 1,2-PDO) when added NaOH increased to 1.0 g, and the selectivity of C–C cleavage products (methanol and ethanol) only increased slightly from 0.7% to 1.9%. These results imply that increase alkali strength of solid base may further enhance its activity for glycerol hydrogenolysis. This conclusion could be illustrated in that hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO proceeds in a consecutively dehydrogenation (to glyceraldehydes), dehydration (to 2-hydroxyacrolein) and hydrogenation steps [45] . Fig. 14 shows the time course of hydrogenolysis of glycerol over Cu 0.4 /Mg 5.6 Al 2 O 8.6 -CP catalyst. Conversion of glycerol increased quickly with reaction time before 20 h, but then increased slowly to 95% at 40 h. The concentration of glycerol in aqueous solution and reaction temperature also exhibited significant impacts on the hydrogenolysis reaction. As it is summarized in Table 5 , both conversion of glycerol and yield of 1,2-PDO increase rapidly with increasing concentration of glycerol. According to the suggested reaction mechanism by Gandarias et al. [52] , this phenomenon could be attributed to that water obstructs the adsorption of glycerol and hydrogen. Raising temperature from 150 °C to 220 °C can accelerate the conversion of glycerol rapidly to >99%, and the selectivity of 1,2-PDO remains higher than 97.0%. No distinct cleavage of C–C bond in glycerol occurred even at higher temperature (see Table 6 ). 4 Conclusion In summery, a highly active hydrotalcite-like catalyst containing copper and solid base was synthesized for hydrogenolysis of glycerol in this work. This kind of copper catalyst exhibited predominant activity because of the homogenously dispersion of copper species in the matrix of hydrotalcite-like solid base. And this kind of solid base supported copper catalyst is also a material full of mesopores that enhanced the accessibility of reactants. A little amount of added NaOH further increased the activity for the desired reaction without obvious cleavage of C–C bond. In a word, homogenously dispersed copper on solid base could be synthesized by thermal decomposition of the layered double hydroxides and this bifunctional catalyst is efficient and attractive for glycerol hydrogenolysis to 1,2-PDO. YBOAKtWd.title: Synthesis of DME via CO hydrogenation on supported Cu-Mn-ZnOx catalyst. Effect of preparation method and reaction conditions
YBOAKtWd.abstract: Effect of preparation method and reaction conditions on the character of supported Cu-Mn-ZnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the synthesis of dimethyl ether (DME) via CO hydrogenation was studied. The activity and the surface component changed greatly with the impregnation step and the calcination temperature. MnO2 and CuO phase were found on the surface of the catalyst when Mn(NO3)2 was first impregnated, which can reduce the conversion of CO. As the calcination temperatures raised to > 450°C, Mn2O3 phase formed in the catalyst, which can help the formation of DME. The experimental studies were conducted on reaction temperature, space velocity, concentration of CO in the feeding gas, and the reaction pressure. The conversion of CO increased quickly with the increasing pressure, while the selectivity of DME changed little with the pressure and hydrocarbons increased with the pressure.

od45WSSm.title: A new solid acid catalyst grafting BF3·Et2O on mesoporous molecular sieve MCM-41
od45WSSm.abstract: A new Solid acid catalyst has been prepared by grafted BF 3•Et2O on mesoporous molecular sieve MCM-41. The solid catalyst would effectively promote the opening reaction of epichlovohydrin with isobutanol to form 1-isobutoxy-3-chloropropanol, and showed a nice activity and selectivity. © 2005 Springer Science+Business Media, Inc.

qgwzqMix.title: Oxidation of Glycerol with Oxygen in a Base-free Aqueous Solution over Pt/AC and Pt/MWNTs Catalysts
qgwzqMix.abstract:
Catalytic oxidation of glycerol with molecular oxygen to glyceric acid was performed in a base-free aqueous solution over
 Pt/MWNTs and Pt/AC catalysts. Pt/MWNTs was more active for the easier accessibility of Pt on the external wall of MWNTs, and
 the initial TOF reached 10.63 mmol min−1/mmol-Pt. The easier accessibility of glycerol to Pt particles on MWNTs was confirmed by Raman.

NivYykx1.title: Effect of the addition of La2O3 on TPR and TPD of CuOγ-Al2O3 catalysts
NivYykx1.abstract: In this paper, the oxidation activity of a CuO γ-Al 2 O 3 catalyst and the effects of addition of La 2 O 3 on a CuO γ-Al 2 O 3 catalyst for the oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) and methane (CH 4 ) were investigated by means of a micro reactor-GC system. The crystal structure of the catalysts, reduction property and surface oxygen desorption and recovery ability of the catalysts were studied by means of XRD, TPR and TPD-MS. Experimental results show that the addition of La 2 O 3 increases the activity of CuO γ-Al 2 O 3 for the oxidation reactions of CO and CH 4 ; the addition of La 2 O 3 promotes the CuO dispersion on γ-Al 2 O 3 which was in the state of non-crystalline CuO and causes the TPR peak of the La 2 O 3 CuO γ-Al 2 O 3 catalyst to move to a lower temperature; the addition of La 2 O 3 has also improves surface oxygen desorption and the recovery ability of the CuO γ-Al 2 O 3 catalyst.

m3hOUegV.title: Synthesis, characterization and antitumor activity of new type binuclear platinum(II) complexes.
m3hOUegV.abstract: Five new type binuclear platinum(II) complexes (a-e) have been synthesized and characterized by elemental analysis, conductivity, thermal analysis, IR, UV, (1)H NMR and mass spectral techniques. The cytotoxicity of the complexes was tested by 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyl tetrazolium bromide (MTT) and sulforhodamine B (SRB) assays. The acute toxicity and antitumor activity of complex ein vivo were also studied. The results indicate that complexes a-d have no activity against HL-60, MCF-7, BGC-823, EJ and HCT-8 cell lines, with a higher IC(50) value (>50 microM). Complex e confers substantially greater cytotoxicity against HL-60, MCF-7, BGC-823, EJ and HCT-8 cell lines with an IC(50) value of 0.02+/-0.009, 1.70+/-0.21, 4.00+/-0.35, 0.98+/-0.02 and 1.02+/-0.21 microM, respectively. LD(50) of complex e is 815.3mg/kg, it was significantly higher than that of cisplatin and carboplatin. Complex e at dose of 4, 12 and 20mg/kg has no activity against mouse hepatocarcinoma H22 and Lewis lung carcinoma in mice, but displays significant activity against human ovarian carcinoma A2780 and human colon carcinoma HCT-116 in nude mice at dose of 12 mg/kg, and activity is similar to that of cisplatin at dose of 4 mg/kg. Complex e at dose of 20mg/kg has no activity against human lung adenocarcinoma A549 in nude mice (P>0.05). The results suggest that the species of amine for the new type binuclear platinum complexes have important effect on their cytotoxicity, and they may be a new class platinum anticancer drugs.

y0ukiAJ1.title: Effect of copper content on Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalysts for the synthesis of dimethyl ether from syngas
y0ukiAJ1.abstract: The activity of Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalysts for dimethyl ether (DME) synthesis from syngas can be affected by the content of copper in the catalyst. The appropriate ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) for catalyst activity was above 0.6, and the conversion of CO and the selectivity of DME reached 78% and 67%, respectively, under the reaction conditions of 2.0 MPa, 250 °C, 1500 h −1 . The results of catalyst characterization by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature- programmed desorption (TPD) showed that the excess CuO in conjunction with mixed oxide was easier reduction, much more beneficial to the activation of CO at lower temperature and higher catalytic activity for DME synthesis. Keywords Manganese Zinc Cu-based catalyst Dimethyl ether Synthesis gas 1 Introduction Dimethyl ether (DME) has attracted much more attention as a potential clean fuel for diesel engines due to its higher cetane number, lower concentration of particulates and NO x in emission [1] . Until now, DME is commercially produced via methanol dehydration, and methanol was synthesized from syngas. Synthesise of DME from syngas in a single step is more favorable in thermodynamic and economical [2,3] . A dual catalyst system consists of a methanol synthesis catalyst (mainly composed of Cu/Zn, Cu/Zn/Al, Cu/Zn/Cr, etc.) and a methanol dehydration catalyst (γ-alumina or zeolites), was popularly reported for direct DME synthesis in published papers [4–10] . Previous works found that Cu–Mn–Zn/Al 2 O 3 catalyst was effective for synthesis of dimethyl ether from syngas [11] , and zeolite as a dehydration component is more favorable than Al 2 O 3 in the step of methanol dehydration to dimethyl ether [12] . Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalysts showed a higher activity even at lower reaction temperatures [13] . Manganese in the Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalyst system improved the dispersion of copper via the strong interaction between manganese and copper to form Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 , and zinc improved the reducibility of Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 [14] . The “synergistic effect” among Cu, Mn and Zn promoted the activity and selectivity of the catalyst for the directly synthesis of DME from synthesis gas [14] . Recently, we found that the activity of the Cu–Mn–Zn/zelolite-Y catalyst could be optimized by adjusting the ratio of Cu/Mn/Zn in the catalyst. In this contribution, we investigated the influence of the content of copper in Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalysts for dimethyl ether synthesis from syngas, and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) of H 2 , CO and NH 3 . 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Catalysts used in this paper were prepared in a coprecipitation impregnation method as follows: an aqueous solution of Cu, Mn and Zn nitrate was dropped with Na 2 CO 3 solution at the same time into a zeolite-Y slurry of water at 60 °C, under vigorously stirring. The pH value of the slurry was controlled at 7.0–8.0 during the coprecipitation. After coprecipitation, the slurry was washed and filtered several times with deionized water, then dried at 160 °C and calcined in air at 450 °C for 4 h. The mole ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) in Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalysts changed from 0.4 to 0.7, while the mole ratio of Mn/Zn is 2 and the total content of metals is is constant in zeolite. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The catalytic reaction was carried out in high-pressure micro-reactor (MCRS8400, China). Catalyst (20–40 mesh, 2 ml, about 1.6 g) was charged into a stainless steel fixed-bed reactor, reduced in H 2 at 270 °C for 3 h under 0.1 MPa. After cooled to 160 °C, the reactant gases, controlled by the mass flow controllers (Brook 5850E, USA) with the mole ratio of H 2 /CO = 3/2, were purged to 2.0 MPa. Typical reaction conditions were 250 °C, 2.0 MPa, and 1500 h −1 . The products in effluent were separated by a Propapak-Q column and analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph with a thermal detector (HP5890, series II, USA). All experimental date were obtained under steady-state conditions that were usually maintained for 8 h. 2.3 Characterizations 2.3.1 X-ray powder diffraction analysis Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out on an automated power X-ray diffractometer (Rigku-D/max-2550/PC, Japan), using Cu Kα radiation, at 40 kV and 300 mA. 2.3.2 Temperature-programmed reduction Temperature-programmed reduction with H 2 (H 2 –TPR) experiments was performed on a catalyst characterization system (AMI-200, USA), which equipped with an on-line mass spectrometer. Catalyst (10 mg) was charged in a U-typed quartz cell, pretreated in argon at 400 °C for 1 h, then reduced under a 10% H 2 /Ar stream (40 ml/min) from 50 to 700 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min. The amount of H 2 ( m / e = 2) in effluent was analyzed by an on-line mass spectrum, and recorded as a function of temperature. 2.3.3 Temperature-programmed desorption of H 2 , CO and NH 3 Temperature-programmed desorption of H 2 , CO and NH 3 were carried out in the same equipment mentioned above in following steps: catalyst (100 mg) was placed in a quartz reactor and first reduced at 270 °C in H 2 flow of 30 ml/min for 1 h, then purged by argon at 400 °C for 1 h; the absorbed material (NH 3 , CO or H 2 ) was introduced into the sample with a flow of 20 ml/min for 0.5 h at 50 °C, then purged by argon steam under the flow of 40 ml/min until the mass spectrum signal reached a constant level. The temperature of rector was programmed to rise with ramp of 10 °C /min, and the amount of desorbed material in effluent was measured by a mass spectrum (NH 3 : m / e = 17 and 14, CO: m / e = 28 and 16, H 2 : m / e = 2) and recorded as a function of temperature. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of the content of copper on catalytic performance The catalytic performances of the Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalyst with different content of copper for DME synthesis are summarized in Table 1 . It can be found that the selectivity of DME remained almost constant with the increased ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn), while the conversion of CO increased from 65.6% to 78.7% with the ratio increased from 0.4 to 0.6, and then changed slightly when the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) up to 0.7. That is, the activity of catalysts for direct synthesis DME depended on the content of copper in a certain extent. 3.2 Characterization of catalysts 3.2.1 XRD analyses The XRD patterns of Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalysts with the different ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) are shown in Fig. 1 . In Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) = 0.4 catalyst, the broad diffraction lines were ascribed to Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 (0 < x < 0.5). As the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) was up to 0.5, ZnMn 2 O 4 was detected together with a predominant CuO, while the diffraction lines of Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 phase became minor. In the Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) = 0.4 catalyst, the calculated atom ratio of Cu/Mn is 1, which favors the formation of Cu 1.5 Mn 1.5 O 4 . Some amount of Zn might enter Cu 1.5 Mn 1.5 O 4 lattice, while its structural changed slightly. In Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) = 0.5 catalyst, the calculated atom ratio of Cu/Mn is 1.5, so copper is excess for the formation of Cu 1.5 Mn 1.5 O 4 , then a segregation of CuO as an independent phase is expected. Mn and Zn with a smaller atom size would enter the CuO lattice, as ZnMn 2 O 4 was detected. Therefore, the structure of the catalysts was changed when the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) was up to 0.5. Similar XRD spectrum of the catalysts (Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) = 0.6, 0.7) was detected, but the intensity of the species phases changed. By correlating the X-ray diffraction data with their catalytic activity, we think that those samples with excess CuO phases in conjunction with the mixed oxide (Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 (0 < x < 0.5) and ZnMn 2 O 4 ) are more active than the single mixed oxide phases. Similar observation is also found from the H 2 –TPR. 3.2.2 Temperature-programmed reduction Fig. 2 shows the H 2 –TPR profiles of Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y catalysts with different ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn). A main reduction peak centered at 210 °C (namely γ) with a minor shoulder peak at 167 °C (namely α), appears on Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) = 0.4 catalyst. According to the XRD results, the γ peak can be attributed to the reduction of copper–manganese oxide (Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 (0 < x < 0.5)). The α peak is the reduction of the amorphous CuO, which cannot be detected by XRD [15,16] . As the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) increased to 0.5, a new reduction peak at 197 °C (namely β) appeared. The intensity of β peak increased with the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn), while the intensity of γ peak decreases, which agrees with the changes of CuO and Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 phases in XRD. The β peak can be assigned to reduction of the excess CuO, and the γ peak can be assigned to reduction of Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 . The shoulder peak (α) is the reduction of the amorphous CuO species, because its intensity increases slightly with the increased ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn). Considering the fact that the catalysts with β reducing peak exhibited higher activity, we think that the CuO (corresponding to β peak) is beneficial to direct synthesis of DME from syngas. 3.2.3 Temperature-programmed desorption of H 2 , CO and NH 3 The TPD profiles of H 2 and CO absorbed on catalysts with different ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) are shown in Figs. 3 and 4 , respectively. Only one H 2 desorption peak at 145 °C appears on all catalysts, and the intensity of H 2 desorption peak change slightly with the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn). It means that the strength and number of the adsorbed H 2 sites on the surfaces of these catalysts cannot be affected by the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn). CO–TPD profiles of catalysts (see Fig. 4 ) show that the desorption temperature of CO shifts from 145 to 135 °C with the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) increasing from 0.4 to 0.6. The intensity of CO desorption peak increases gradually with the increased ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn), and then maintained almost constant as the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) increases from 0.6 to 0.7. It means that the capability of absorbed CO depends on the content of copper in the catalysts. The NH 3 –TPD (seen Fig. 5 ) shows that the catalysts with the different ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) have the similar area of desorption peak of NH 3 at about 270 °C. It indicates that the number and strength of the acid sites on the catalysts are independent on the content of copper. The acidity of the catalysts for dimethyl ether synthesis comes from the support, such as zeolite in the Cu–Mn–Zn/zeolite-Y. In the preparation process, some amount of metallic ions might be exchanged into the inner pore, and/or supercage of zeolite. Cu 2+ can be precipitated easily compared with Mn 2+ and Zn 2+ , and the following precipitation of manganese and/or zinc covered mainly on the outer surface of zeolite. We think that the content of copper hardly effects on the acidity of the catalysts when the total content of metal is constant. It has been confirmed that the direct synthesis of dimethyl ether from syngas proceeded via the synthesis of methanol on metallic components and a consecutive dehydration of methanol on the acidic support [4,17] . So the activity of the catalysts depends both on the capability of carbon monoxide hydrogenation and the capability of dehydration. The TPD results show that the activity of dehydration and the capability of chemisorption of H 2 are similar in these catalysts, but the strength of chemisorption of CO decreases slightly and the number of the sites increases with the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) increasing. Published papers [18–21] showed that CO is mainly adsorbed on the dispersed copper, the strength of CO adsorbed on Cu + is stronger than on Cu 0 and the appropriate ratio of Cu 0 /Cu + is beneficial to enhance the activity of CO hydrogenation. According to the H 2 –TPR and XRD results, we think that the copper in Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 phase in the catalyst with a Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) = 0.4 ratio possesses more positive charges than that of excess CuO phase combined with the mixed oxide in the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) up to 0.5 catalyst after reduction. On this assumption, the strength of CO adsorbed decreases with the increased ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn). The higher activity of the catalysts with a Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) ratio up to 0.6, may be due to the appropriate ratio of Cu 0 /Cu + . Therefore, the effect of the Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) ratio on the catalytic activity is their chemisorption capability of CO, which depends strongly on the content of copper and the interaction within copper, manganese and zinc. 4 Conclusions As a conclusion, we think that increasing copper content in Cu–Mn–Zn/Y catalyst is conducive to enhance its activity for direct synthesis of DME from CO hydrogenation. Catalyst with a Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) ratio up to 0.6 exhibits the best performance. XRD results showed that excess CuO phases with the minor mixed oxide phases present in the catalysts when the ratio of Cu/(Cu + Mn + Zn) up to 0.6. H 2 –TPR results showed that the excess CuO phases in conjunction with mixed oxide are easily reduced than the CuO in Cu 1+ x Mn 2− x O 4 . TPD of H 2 , CO and NH 3 adsorption results show that the content of copper mainly affects the adsorption of CO on catalyst surface, and the copper reduced from the excess CuO phases is beneficial to the activation of CO at lower temperature. These results indicate that the catalysts with the excess CuO phases in conjunction with mixed oxide are more active than the mixed oxide phases. 38BEeViG.title: Silica-supported poly-γ-aminopropylsiloxane palladium (Pd 2+)-transition metal (Cu2+) complex: A new catalyst system for Heck reaction
38BEeViG.abstract: A new silica-supported poly-γ-aminopropysiloxane transition metal (Cu2+) and palladium (Pd2+) catalyst has been prepared from organic silica via immobilization on fumed silica, followed by treatment with Cu(OAc)2 and PdCl2 in ethanol. The catalyst is efficient for Heck arylation of aryl iodides with alkene. The effects of reaction temperature and Pd2+ content on catalytic properties have also been studied. Pd2+ has been found to improve the catalytic performance, reducing the reaction temperature (70°C) and the induction period. It provides an economic way to synthesize unsymmetrical trans-stilbenes.

S8nBHvo5.title: Influence of alloying platinum on the hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene over PtM/ZrO2 catalysts with M=Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu
S8nBHvo5.abstract:
Hydrogenation of chloronitrobenzene (CNB) over PtM/ZrO2 (M= Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) catalysts has been studied in ethanol at 303 K and normal pressure. 
 The results show that the hydrogenetion of CNB can be carried out over PtM/ZrO2 catalysts. The order of the hydrogenation rates of CNB is p>m>o, and the yield of chloroaniline (CAN) is p>o>m. 
 PtFe/ZrO2 catalysts shows the highest catalytic activity on the hydrogenation of CNB. PtNi/ZrO2 
 catalyst shows good yield of CNB to CAN, and 93.3 mol% for o-CAN, 98.0 mol% for m-CAN 
 and 98.5 mol% for p-CAN, respectively.

o8pN6BOy.title: Methanol synthesis by co2 hydrogenation over titanium modified γ-Al2O3 supported copper catalysts
o8pN6BOy.abstract: A titanium-modified γ-Al2O3 supported copper catalyst has been prepared and used for methanol synthesis by CO2 hydrogenation. The addition of Ti to the CuO/γ-Al2O3 catalyst enhances the activity in CO2 hydrogenation greatly and makes the copper in the catalyst exist in much smaller crystallites. The effect of contact time on the relative selectivity (κ=SCH3OH/SCO) and selectivity of methanol was also investigated. The results indicated that methanol was formed directly from the hydroge;nation of CO2.

mcr4dqs3.title: Study of Partial Oxidation and CO2 Reforming of Methane on Co Based Catalysts
mcr4dqs3.abstract: The effects of metal-support interaction and Co loading on catalytic performance in combined partial oxidation and CO2 reforming of methane were studied by TPR, XRD, and catalytic tests. Catalytic activities of Co based catalysts depended greatly on interaction strength between metal and support. Co/γ-Al2O3 and Co/SiO2 catalysts showed poor catalytic activity because the interaction between Co and support was either too strong or too weak. Alternatively, Co/α-Al2O3 catalyst showed excellent catalytic activity since interaction between Co and α-Al2O3 was suitable. Co loading on Co/α-Al2O3 catalysts had great effect on catalytic activity. Low Co loading Co/α-Al2O3 catalysts made phase transfer from Co0 to CoAl2O4 easy and thus deactivated the catalyst. However, too high Co loading Co/α-Al2O3 catalysts led to carbon deposition during reaction and large particles of Co metal were the active centers of carbon deposition.

MKJWWRjg.title: Catalytic Oxidation of Toluene, Acetone and Ethyl Acetate on a New Pt-Pd/Stainless Steel Wire Mesh Catalyst
MKJWWRjg.abstract: A new volatile organic compound (VOC) combustion catalyst of 0.1%Pt-0.5%Pd/stainless steel wire mesh (SSWM) was prepared via anodic oxidation treatment. The result of activity tests for complete oxidation of toluene, acetone, and ethyl acetate showed that 0.1%Pt-0.5%Pd/stainless steel wire mesh catalyst had good catalytic activity and thermal stability. The total oxidation temperature for toluene, acetone, and ethyl acetate was at 220, 260, and 280 °C for the catalyst calcined at 500 °C, respectively. The catalyst and stainless steel wire mesh support were characterized by means of scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS), and ultrasonic vibration tests. The SEM results indicated that a typical donga structure layer appeared on the surface of stainless steel wire mesh support after anodic oxidation procedure. This typical anodic oxidation film was favorable for dispersing Pd and Pt components.

c62EguNy.title: Alkylation of 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene with γ-butyrolactone catalyzed by AlCl3 and Nafion-H
c62EguNy.abstract: The alkylation product 4-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)butyric acid was synthesized via the reaction of 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene with γ-butyrolactone catalyzed by AlCl3 at room temperature. The catalyst amount and reaction time were important factors affecting the product yield. The γ-butyrolactone could be converted to the product quantitatively under certain reaction conditions, but it was not suitable for industrial application because of its environmental pollution. Thus, some polymer resins were chosen to replace AlCl3 to make this process much more friendly to the environment. Nafion-H was the best among the polymer resins in terms of both the product selectivity and yield. The yield of 4-(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)butyric acid increased with the increase of reaction temperature and reached the maximum value of 84.5% at 200°C, while the selectivity was about 90%. Nafion-H could be reused after simply washing and drying, but its activity decreased by 4-5% with each use. A reaction mechanism under the Nafion-H catalysis was proposed, in which the activation of γ-butyrolactone was the key step.

LJCK2qxq.title: Preparation of ZnCl2-modified ion exchange resin and its catalytic activity for esterification of ethanol and acetic acid under microwave
LJCK2qxq.abstract: An ion-exchange method was used to prepare a ZnCl2-modified ion exchange resin. Several factors such as impregnation liquid concentration, ion-exchange time, and solvent used in the preparation were examined. Optimal preparation conditions for the ZnCl2-modified ion exchange resin included the use of deionized water as solvent, 0.15% concentration (mass fraction) of the ZnCl2 solution, and ion-exchange time of 30 h. The H+ exchange capacity of the ZnCl2-modified ion exchange resin was investigated by acid-base titration. UV-Vis spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and N2 adsorption were used to characterize the catalyst. Gas chromatography was used to determine the catalyst activity for the esterification of ethanol and acetic acid under microwave. The acid strength and catalytic activity of the ion exchange resin were improved after being modified by ZnCl2, and the H+ exchange capacity of the modified catalyst is about 1.5 times that of the original one. Moreover, the skeleton structure of the modified resin has not changed. Only a small blue shift and reduction of the absorption intensity can be observed on the corresponding UV absorption peak, and the BET surface area decreases slightly. The ZnCl2-modified catalyst showed a higher reactivity in the water system and a better repeatability as compared to the unmodified one.

JGCxZx0h.title: Preparation of Mesoporous Alumina and Its Application in Dehydration of Methanol to Dimethyl Ether
JGCxZx0h.abstract: Ordered mesoporous alumina was synthesized by the homogeneous precipitation method from aqueous Al(NO3)3·9H2O solution using cationic cetyltrimethylammonium bromide as template.Characterization results showed that the surface area,average pore diameter,and pore volume of the calcined mesoporous alumina are 179.8 m2/g,5.4 nm and 0.3 cm3/g,respectively.Over the mesoporous alumina,the space time yield of dimethyl ether(DME) in methanol dehydration reaches 15.4 g/(g·h) at 280 oC and 30 h-1 with 90.2% methanol conversion.The activity of the mesoporous alumina samples for methanol dehydration to DME was compared.The detected activity for methanol dehydration strongly depends on the surface acid density of the alumina.

GtC6H1Pd.title: The dispersed states of copper species on CuO/ZrO2 catalysts and its influence on the catalytic performance
GtC6H1Pd.abstract: Copper/Zirconia catalysts were prepared by impregnation method and characterized by XRD, TPR and TPD-MS. It was concluded that four oxygen desorption peaks from two different temperature ranges were related to oxygen species of surface adsorption, highly-dispersed copper oxide on ZrO2 and CuO phase, respectively, and the highly-dispersed copper oxide was easily reduced, which leads to a dramatic increase in oxidation activity.

qSbHuprW.title: One-step hydrogenation-esterification of aldehyde and acid to ester over bifunctional Pt catalysts: A model reaction as novel route for catalytic upgrading of fast pyrolysis bio-oil
qSbHuprW.abstract: The bio-oil from fast pyrolysis of biomass cannot be used effectively as engine fuel because of its high corrosiveness and instability mainly due to substantial amounts of organic acids and reactive aldehydes. In this paper a treatment of acids and aldehydes in the bio-oil was focused on. A novel upgrading method named one-step hydrogenation - esterification (OHE) was established to convert acids and aldehydes to stable and combustible components. Acetaldehyde (butyl aldehyde) and acetic acid were chosen as model compounds for the OHE reaction over platinum catalysts that acidic supports such as HZSM-5 or amorphous aluminum silicate were adopted. The catalysts were bifunctional, which means they have properties of hydrogenation and esterification. Experiments showed this, and it was a feasible route to convert these main unstable components of bio-oil to esters through this simple and effective OHE reaction. The catalysts with high surface area, large pore size distribution, small metal particles,and strong acid sites may be beneficial for the OHE reaction. © 2008 American Chemical Society.

Dz7CUUJF.title: Reforming of CH<sub>4</sub> with CO<sub>2</sub>and O<sub>2</sub>to produce syngas over CaO modified Ni/SiO<sub>2</sub> catalysts in a fluidized bed reactor
Dz7CUUJF.abstract:
Methane reforming by carbon dioxide and oxygen was investigated over 5 wt.%Ni/CaO-SiO2 catalyst in a fluidized-bed reactor. The catalyst exhibited high activity and good stability at stoichiometric methane, carbon
 oxide and oxygen feed. Effects of calcium loading, space velocities, reaction temperatures and the feed gas compositions for
 this combined reaction were investigated. These results indicated that Ni/CaO-SiO2 is more effective and stable. The catalyst performance, stability, structure, dispersion of nickel and carbon deposition
 of the modified and unmodified catalysts were investigated by a series of characterization techniques. Results showed that
 catalysts modified with CaO improved their stability better than the pure nickel-based catalysts.

CzRLKV3L.title: A novel catalyst for DME synthesis from CO hydrogenation
CzRLKV3L.abstract: The effect of manganese on the dispersion, reduction behavior and active states of surfaces of γ-Al 2 O 3 supported copper catalysts was investigated by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and XPS technologies. The relationship between the area of metallic copper and the activity of dimethyl ether (DME) synthesis from CO/H 2 was also investigated. The catalytic activity over Cu-MnO x /γ-Al 2 O 3 catalyst for CO hydrogenation is higher than that of Cu/γ-Al 2 O 3 . The adding of manganese increases the dispersion of the supported copper oxide. For the CuO/γ-Al 2 O 3 catalyst, there are two reducible copper oxide species; α- and β-peaks are attributed to the reduction of highly dispersed copper oxide species and bulk CuO species, respectively. For the CuO-MnO x /γ-Al 2 O 3 catalyst, four reduction peaks are observed. The α-peak is attributed to the reduction of high dispersed copper oxide species; β-peak is ascribed to the reduction of bulk CuO; γ-peak is ascribed to the high-dispersed CuO interacting with Mn; and δ-peak is attributed to the reduction of the manganese oxide interacting with copper oxide. XPS results showed that Cu + mostly existed on the working surface of the Cu-Mn/γ-Al 2 O 3 catalysts. Cu promoted the catalytic activity with positive charge, which was formed by means of long path exchange function between CuOMn. These results indicate that there are synergistic interactions between the copper and manganese oxide, which are responsible for the high activity of CO hydrogenation.

oX4G9mHu.title: Effect of ZrO2 on surface oxygen performance of Mn-O/γ-Al2O3 catalyst
oX4G9mHu.abstract: TPD-MS and TPR techniques were used to study the desorption and reduction properties of surface oxygen over Mn-O/γ-Al2O3 and Mn-O/ZrO2+γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and their reproduction. The solid structures were characterized by XRD. The results show that there exist highly-dispersed Mn-O species, MnO2, Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 phases over the catalysts. ZrO2 cannot change the TPR and TPD feature peaks of Mn-O/γ-Al2O3, but increase the amount of crystalline MnO2, and meanwhile also increase reduction properties of Mn4+ and Mn3+.
