iy6V8WQV.title: Conversion of Biomass-Derived Carbohydrates to Methyl Lactate Using Sn-MCM-41 and SnO_2/SiO_2
iy6V8WQV.abstract: Biomass is a promising alternative for sustainable supply of precious intermediates and fine chemicals to the chemical industry.Lactic acid(2-hydroxypropanoic acid) and its related alkyl lactates are widely used in chemicals,food,pharmaceuticals,and cosmetic products.A study of the liquid-phase conversion of biomass-derived carbohydrates directly to methyl lactate catalyzed by Sn-MCM-41 and SnO2/SiO2 in subcritical methanol is presented.With glucose as substrate,methyl lactate yield reached 40.3% under the optimal reaction conditions.Fresh and used catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction,N2 adsorption-desorption,transmission electron microscopy,infrared spectroscopy with pyridine adsorption,and NH3 temperature-programmed desorption techniques.Methyl lactate yield was closely related to reaction temperature,reaction time,and the acidic site amount of catalysts.The catalysts were active and can be reused without significant decrease in the catalytic activity after being used for five recycles.The mesoporous structure and acid sites of the reused catalysts did not change much and the leaching of Sn was less than 0.15%.They were easy and relatively rapid synthesis,operational simplicity,reusability,and safe handling.

oWdFE1Xv.title: Cold Plasma-Assisted Selective Catalytic Reduction of NO over B_2O_3/γ-Al_2O_3
oWdFE1Xv.abstract: A plasma-assisted catalytic system for the selective catalytic reduction of NO with methane was investigated.NO2,HCHO,CH3NO,and CH3NO2 were the reactive intermediates generated by the plasma.The further reactions of these intermediates on the catalyst during the thermal catalytic stage resulted in the conversion of NOx to N2,which was verified by temperature-programmed surface reaction characterization.B2O3/γ-Al2O3 was the best catalyst with the maximum conversion of NOx to N2 increasing from 33.4% on γ-Al2O3 to 51.0% on 10 wt% B2O3/γ-Al2O3 at 300 oC.NH3-TPD characterization showed that the acidity of the catalyst is important for the reduction of NOx by the intermediates generated by the plasma.NOx-TPD showed that the adsorbed NOx species on the catalysts also played a role in the conversion of NOx.

EgOTUAkV.title: The preparation of Ag/CeO_2-ZnO catalyst used for preparing hydrogen from methanol by partial oxidation
EgOTUAkV.abstract: The preparation of Ag/CeO_(2)-ZnO catalyst used for preparing hydrogen from methanol by partial oxidation and the effect of reaction conditions of the process on the catalytic performance are studied.It is found that the loading of Ag in the catalyst,the calcinating and reaction temperature and the ratio of reaction gases have a significant effect on the catalyst performance.When the preparation conditions of the catalyst and the reaction conditions of the process are controlled within a certain scope,the Ag/CeO_(2)-ZnO catalyst used for the preparation of hydrogen from methanol by partial oxidation has high catalytic activity and selectivity.

vdEwegwq.title: Effect of fuels on the nanosized ceria powder by combustion method.
vdEwegwq.abstract: Nanosized CeO2 powder was synthesized by fuel-nitrate low-temperature combustion method.The effect of novel fuels(glycerol and manninol) was studied.The gel decomposition was analyzed by TG-DTA,and the properties of the powders were characterized by XRD,nitrogen adsorption/desorption and SEM.The results showed that nanosized CeO2 powder prepared with manninol had smaller crystalline size(10.1 nm) and higher BET area(87.1 m2·g-1).

lyuRomPK.title: Preparation of ZnCl_2-Modified Ion Exchange Resin and Its Catalytic Activity for Esterification of Ethanol and Acetic Acid under Microwave
lyuRomPK.abstract: An ion-exchange method was used to prepare a ZnCl2-modified ion exchange resin.Several factors such as impregnation liquid concentration,ion-exchange time,and solvent used in the preparation were examined.Optimal preparation conditions for the ZnCl2-modified ion exchange resin included the use of deionized water as solvent,0.15% concentration(mass fraction) of the ZnCl2 solution,and ion-exchange time of 30 h.The H+ exchange capacity of the ZnCl2-modified ion exchange resin was investigated by acid-base titration.UV-Vis spectroscopy,Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy,scanning electron microscopy,and N2 adsorption were used to characterize the catalyst.Gas chromatography was used to determine the catalyst activity for the esterification of ethanol and acetic acid under microwave.The acid strength and catalytic activity of the ion exchange resin were improved after being modified by ZnCl2,and the H+ exchange capacity of the modified catalyst is about 1.5 times that of the original one.Moreover,the skeleton structure of the modified resin has not changed.Only a small blue shift and reduction of the absorption intensity can be observed on the corresponding UV absorption peak,and the BET surface area decreases slightly.The ZnCl2-modified catalyst showed a higher reactivity in the water system and a better repeatability as compared to the unmodified one.

R57IPhGP.title: An enhanced plasma-catalytic method for DeNO(x) in simulated flue gas at room temperature.
R57IPhGP.abstract: A combined adsorption-discharge plasma process was proposed for DeNOx in simulated flue gas at room temperature. The conversion of NOx to N2 could achieve 95% in the process of NOx storage and reduction with NH3 under simulated flue gas conditions.

amQdGsf7.title: The effect of preparation parameters on the structure and catalytic performance of Ce-Pt-Pd/SSWM stainless steel wire mesh catalyst
amQdGsf7.abstract: A new type of catalyst consisting of a porous anodic oxidation membrane formed on the surface of stainless steel wire mesh and active compounds of cerium,platinum and palladium dispersed on the support surface was successfully prepared.The catalyst shows good activity for the oxidation of toluene,acetone and ethyl acetate.The results show that the operating parameters affect the formation of porous anodic oxidation membrane and thereby affect the catalytic activity subsequent.The catalyst, prepared by using 10%H_2SO_4 as electrolyte and current density 1.0 A,shows a good catalytic activity and stability.

L1BHlSBH.title: Characterization and Catalytic Properties of CuO/TiO_2/γ-Al_2O_3 for NO+CO Reaction
L1BHlSBH.abstract: The catalytic activity and properties of w%CuO/15%TiO2/γ-Al2O3 in NO+CO reaction were examined using a micro-reactor gas chromatography reaction system. When pretreated by air and H2, the catalysts had 100% NO conversion at 325 and 275 ℃, respectively. The XRD analysis could only detect γ-Al2O3 crystal diffraction and weak CuO crystal diffraction peaks after 15%CuO loading. There were two H2-TPR reduction peaks in CuO-TiO2/γ-Al2O3, the α peak due to the highly dispersed CuO which spread on γ-Al2O3 surface and the other peak due to the highly dispersed CuO which dispersed on 15%TiO2/γ-Al2O3 surface. The DRIFTS analysis showed that catalysts with pretreatment in air or H2 atmosphere adsorbed NO+CO gases, and the N2O adsorption peaks appeared at 200 and 150 ℃,respectively.

dViABHa2.title: Synthesis of α-Tetralone by Intramolecular Acylation of 4-Phenylbutyric Acid in a Fixed Bed Reactor
dViABHa2.abstract: The effect of different catalysts,reaction temperature and calcination temperature on the performance of the catalyst for synthesis of α-tetralone by intramolecular acylation of 4-phenylbutyric acids in fixed bed were investigated.The results showed that H-Beta zeolite which was calcined at 900 ℃ exhibited high activity and stability in the reaction.The average conversion of 4-phenylbutyric acid was 98.0% and the average yield of α-tetralone was 81.2% after reaction 10 h at 220 ℃.

0WpKUnNT.title: Effect of Calcination Temperature on Characteristics and Performance of Ni/MgO Catalyst for CO_2 Reforming of Toluene
0WpKUnNT.abstract: A Ni/MgO catalyst for CO2 reforming of toluene was prepared by impregnating MgO with Ni(NO3) 2.During calcination,some of the NiO diffused into the MgO and formed a solid solution structure of NiO-MgO,which was analyzed by Raman spectroscopy.In the temperature-programmed reduction with hydrogen analysis,only a small part of the Ni species in the outermost layer was reduced to metallic Ni at 700℃.The calcination temperature played a key role in determining the subsequent catalytic activity of Ni/MgO,consequently the catalyst calcined at 600℃ had the highest activity.This catalyst also had the highest surface concentration of reduced Ni,which probably accounted for its high activity.During the reforming tests,a small amount of coke was deposited on Ni/MgO catalyst.Polyaromatic compounds were observed by Raman spectroscopy.The coke was probably responsible for the activity loss of Ni/MgO.

TmTcThqY.title: Preparation process and characterization of new Pt/stainless steel wire mesh catalyst designed for volatile organic compounds elimination
TmTcThqY.abstract: A novel 0.1% Pd-0.05% (mass fraction) Pt/stainless steel wire mesh catalyst was prepared for volatile organic compounds (VOCs) elimination. The catalyst was synthesized by stainless steel wire mesh as support and then treated by anodic oxidation technology to develop a porous membrane on the support. During the anodic oxidation process, various electrolytes were used to investigate the formation of porous membrane. And the catalytic performance of the catalysts was tested by using toluene and acetone combustion as model reaction. The temperatures of complete toluene and acetone conversion were decreased to 180 °C and 240 °C, respectively. The morphologies of the stainless steel wire mesh supports and catalysts were characterized by means of scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR).

Wy8fIsXS.title: Study on bio-oil upgrading reaction using HZSM-5under super-critical ethanol and analysis method
Wy8fIsXS.abstract: High-boiling point fractions (HBF) of bio-oil upgrading reaction using HZSM-5with different Si/Al ratios were carried out under different reaction conditions (super-critical, sub-critical, conventional ethanol). Quantitative31P NMR spectroscopy was used to measure the hydroxyl and carboxyl content in the HBF of bio-oil before and after upgrading. The results showed that super-critical could largely improve the conversion of aliphatic hydroxyl moieties, but could not conducive to the conversion of noncondensed phenolic hydroxyl moieties. Carboxylic acids were almost eliminated under all upgrading reaction conditions. The aliphatic hydroxyl moieties were more easily converted by using stronger acidic HZSM-5, and the amount of the noncondensed phenolic hydroxyl moieties decreased evidently by using weaker acidic HZSM-5 (Si/Al=300).

wajRbD3L.title: Photo-catalytic degradation of phenolic wastewater by superfine titanium dioxide
wajRbD3L.abstract: TiO2 photocatalysts were prepared by sol-gel method with stearic acid(STA) as an anti-reuniting agent.The properties of TiO2 photocatalyst were examined by using BET,XRD and Raman techniques.It was found that STA could restrain the sintering of TiO2 grain size and raise the phase transfor temperature of TiO2 crystal.As the diameter of TiO2 particles decreases,the Raman peak shifts to blue and the energy alternation increases slightly.The catalytic activity reached maximal at the molar ratio of 1.5 STA to 1 titanium(IV) tetrabutanoxide,calcining temperature of 450 ℃ and catalyst density of 2 g·L-1.After irradiation of 300 W Hg lamp for 2 hours,the phenolic degradation rate was 97.0%.

fpM8iJ2r.title: Transesterification of rapeseed oil to biodiesel using La_2O_3 loaded with KF
fpM8iJ2r.abstract: Biodiesel produced by the transesterification of rapeseed oil is a promising alternative fuel.In this work,an environmental benign process for the production of biodiesel from rapeseed oil with solid base catalyst was developed.KF /La2O3 produced by impregnation was firstly adopted for the production of biodiesel.A study for optimizing the reaction conditions such as the loading amount of KF,the methanol to oil molar ratio,the amount of catalyst,and the reaction time were performed.15% KF/La2O3 had the best catalytic activity.Under the optimum conditions,the catalyst calcination temperature of 873 K for 4 hours,methanol to oil molar ratio of 12,reaction temperature of 65 ℃,catalyst amount of 3%,and reaction time of 1 hour,the oil conversion was 94.3 %.

Rxt5DQz7.title: Mesoporous Li/ZrO2 as a solid base catalyst for biodiesel production from transesterification of soybean oil with methanol
Rxt5DQz7.abstract: Research Highlights ► Mesoporous 0.1M/ZrO 2 (M=Li, Na, K, Mg, Ca) were synthesized by sol-gel method. ► High yields of biodiesel production were achieved on 0.1Li/ZrO 2 and 0.1K/ZrO 2 . ► FAME yields on different catalysts were correlated to their basic properties.

Zlbo5Yjv.title: Room temperature transesterification of soybean oil to biodiesel catalyzed by rod-like Ca xSiO x + 2 solid base
Zlbo5Yjv.abstract: Rod-like Ca xSiO x + 2 catalysts were synthesized by using one-pot hydrothermal method. Catalysts calcined at 550 °C were used in the transesterification reaction of soybean oil with methanol. Under methanol reflux condition, FAME yields of 82% and 95% were achieved on Ca 4SiO 6 in a reaction time of 1 and 2 h, separately. Also, the FAME yields on different Ca xSiO x + 2 catalysts were correlated with their basic properties. Besides, a FAME yield of ca. 80% can be achieved under room temperature over Ca 4SiO 6 catalyst. © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

UdtKQn8u.title: Molybdenum carbide-catalyzed conversion of renewable oils into diesel-like hydrocarbons
UdtKQn8u.abstract: In the paper, we report for the first time that the conversion of renewable oils into diesel-like hydrocarbon mixtures can be realized on molybdenum carbides with high activity and selectivity. The molybdenum carbide catalyst exhibited much better resistance to leaching than noble metals and could be reused consecutively for sixteen times without deactivation. Mechanism investigations indicated that molybdenum carbide and palladium showed different reaction selectivities and it was speculated that the level of difficulty in acyl-to-alkyl rearrangement of surface acyl intermediates on molybdenum carbide and palladium resulted in the different product selectivity. Copyright © 2011 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

xlA2aspN.title: Transesterification of sunflower oil to biodiesel on ZrO2 supported La2O3 catalyst.
xlA2aspN.abstract: ZrO(2) supported La(2)O(3) catalyst prepared by impregnation method was examined in the transesterification reaction of sunflower oil with methanol to produce biodiesel. It was found that the catalyst with 21 wt% loaded La(2)O(3) and calcined at 600 degrees C showed the optimum activity. The basic property of the catalyst was studied by CO(2)-TPD, and the results showed that the fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) yield was related to their basicity. The catalyst was also characterized by TG-DTA, XRD, FTIR, SEM and TEM, and the mechanism for the formation of basic sites was discussed. It was also found that the crystallite size of support ZrO(2) decreased by loading of La(2)O(3), and the model of the solid-state reaction on the surface of La(2)O(3)/ZrO(2) catalyst was proposed. Besides, the influence of various reaction variables on the conversion was investigated.

XJ0GENwL.title: Nanostructured molybdenum carbides supported on carbon nanotubes as efficient catalysts for one-step hydrodeoxygenation and isomerization of vegetable oils
XJ0GENwL.abstract: Nanostructured molybdenum carbides supported on multi-walled carbon nanotubes (Mo 2C/CNTs) with different loadings were prepared by carbothermal hydrogen reduction method and characterized with SEM, Raman, HAADF-STEM and XRD. Raman spectra showed that the specific G-band structure of carbon nanotubes promoted the formation of molybdenum carbide at lower temperatures. Compared with noble metals, molybdenum carbide exhibited better catalytic activity and resistance to leaching. The Mo 2C/CNTs catalyst also showed high activity and selectivity for one-step conversion of vegetable oils into branched diesel-like hydrocarbons, which provided a promising approach to prepare high-grade diesel fuels from renewable resources. © 2011 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

UrbbDVpr.title: One-pot synthesized mesoporous Ca/SBA-15 solid base for transesterification of sunflower oil with methanol
UrbbDVpr.abstract: Graphical abstract Research highlights ▶ A series of Ca/SBA-15 samples with Ca/Si molar ratio of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5 were prepared by using a one-pot synthesis method and used in the transesterification of sunflower oil with methanol. The mesoporous structure of SBA-15 was well preserved with Ca/Si ratio up to 0.5. ▶ Compared with 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample, the Ca/SBA-15 not only showed a better calcium species distribution, but also showed higher BET surface area and larger medium basic sites. ▶ A biodiesel yield of as high as 99.1% was achieved on the 0.5Ca/SBA-15 catalyst at a reaction temperature of 200 °C for 8 h. At the meantime, no deactivation was found on Ca/SBA-15 sample prepared by one-pot synthesis method in the transesterification reaction, which showed a much better stability than that of prepared by conventional impregnation method. ▶ A water content of up to 5% and/or free fatty acids (FFAs) of 3% did not affect the catalytic activity of Ca/SBA-15 catalyst in the transesterification reaction. Abstract A series of Ca/SBA-15 samples with Ca/Si atomic ratios of 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5 were prepared by using a one-pot synthesis method. They were used in the transesterification of sunflower oil with methanol. For comparison, 0.3Ca/SBA-15 was also synthesized by an incipient impregnation method (0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM). Small-angle XRD, N 2 adsorption, TEM, SEM, TG-DTA, FTIR, CO 2 -TPD techniques were used to determine the textual structure and physicochemical properties of Ca/SBA-15 samples. The mesoporous structure of SBA-15 was well preserved with Ca/Si ratios up to 0.5. Compared with 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample, the Ca/SBA-15 showed not only a better calcium species distribution, but also higher BET surface area and larger medium basic sites. A biodiesel yield of as high as 99.1% was achieved on the 0.5Ca/SBA-15 catalyst at a reaction temperature of 200 °C for 8 h. In the meantime, no deactivation was found after five cycles on Ca/SBA-15 sample prepared by one-pot synthesis method in the transesterification reaction, which showed a much better stability than that of prepared by conventional impregnation method. Besides, a water content of up to 5% and/or free fatty acids (FFAs) content of 3% did not affect the catalytic activity of Ca/SBA-15 catalyst in the transesterification reaction. Keywords Ca/SBA-15 CaO Solid base Transesterification Biodiesel 1 Introduction Petrochemical sources such as coal and natural gases, which are finite and will be exhausted shortly, are supplying the majority of the energy needs of the world nowadays. The utilization of alternative renewable fuels is therefore being more and more attracting. Biodiesel, a mixture of alkyl esters obtained from vegetable or animal oils, is a promising nontoxic and biodegradable fuel arising from biomass [1,2] . Biodiesel is usually produced by the transesterification of triglycerides with methanol and/or ethanol in the presence of a catalyst [3] . Alkaline catalysts are more widely investigated because the rate of transesterification reactions catalyzed by alkaline catalysts is much faster than those of reactions catalyzed by the acid catalysts [4,5] . Homogeneous basic catalysts such as sodium or potassium hydroxide are conventionally used for the transesterification reaction because these traditional homogeneous catalysts have certain advantages, including high activity (complete conversion within 1 h) and mild reaction conditions (65 °C and 1 atm). However, the removal of these catalysts is technically difficult, and a large amount of wastewater was produced during biodiesel separation and cleaning [6] . Heterogeneous basic catalysts have been widely studied in the last decades in order to circumvent the difficulties with homogeneous catalysts. They have some outstanding advantages, such as simpler separation and no toxicity, no corrosion, or no environmental pollution [7] . Many kinds of solid bases have been investigated for this purpose, including alkali and alkali earth metal oxides [8,9] , rare earth metal oxides [10–13] , calcined hydrotalcites [14,15] , alkali earth metal oxide and rare earth metal oxide complexes [16,17] , zeolites [18] , anion exchanged resins [19,20] . A leaching problem has been raised up in most of the catalysts just in the past several years [8,9,21,22] . CaO is the most attractive catalyst among the insoluble alkali and alkali earth metal oxides because of its high transesterification activity [23–25] . A large amount of leached species, however, was also observed because of the formation of Ca diglyceroxide when glycerol is present [26] . Because extensive leaching may threaten the reusability and the environmental sustainability of catalyst, pure CaO seems not adaptable for industrial applications. Thus, it is important to investigate novel heterogeneous basic catalysts that are both active and stable for the transesterification reaction. New opportunities have been opened up in many areas of chemistry and material science since the discovery of mesoporous silica molecular sieves [27,28] . Due to its desirable features, e.g. tailorable pore size, high degree of structural ordering, ease of synthesis, larger pore size, thicker pore walls and higher hydrothermal/thermal stability, SBA-15 has been extensively studied in the last decade [29,30] . Nowadays, SBA-15 has achieved numerous applications in the fields of catalysis, adsorptions, separations, water purification, and advanced optical devices because of its unique physicochemical properties [31–36] . SBA-15 based solid strong bases have been widely studied in the field of catalysis because of their unique property [37–43] . Srivastava et al. synthesized cyclic carbonates by using adenine-modified Ti-SBA-15 solid base as a catalyst [37] . Sujandi et al. also successfully prepared the short-channeled amino-functionalized-SBA-15 catalysts with high performance in Knoevenagel and Claisen–Schmidt condensations as well as in Henry reactions. Both organic and inorganic compounds, including amino [39] , magnesium [40,41] , and calcium [42] modified SBA-15 have been achieved by Zhu's group. Albuquerque et al. reported the first use of CaO/SBA-15 type solid base catalyst in biodiesel production, but the reusability of the catalyst was not reported [43] . It is worth noting that Mg and/or Ca modified SBA-15 solid base catalyst were all prepared by an impregnation-like method. This required two steps of calcination for the formation of solid base which of course led to more energy consumption. On the other hand, although solid strong/super bases can catalyze various reactions in mild conditions, their industrial applications are limited by the difficulties in synthesis and storage [44] . Thus, preparation of less strong but more stable solid bases seems more promising in industrial applications. Here, we present a one-pot synthesis method to prepare calcium loaded SBA-15 solid base. The physicochemical properties of the resultant materials are characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), N 2 adsorption, transmission and scanning electron microscopy (TEM and SEM), thermogravimetric analyzers (TG), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and CO 2 -temperature-programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) techniques. For comparison, Ca/SBA-15 was also synthesized by the impregnation method (0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM). The catalytic activity of these catalysts was tested by the transesterification reaction of sunflower oil with methanol. The differences between samples prepared by the two methods were also identified and discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Sample preparation Ca/SBA-15 samples were synthesized according to standard literature procedures [29,30] . In a typical synthesis, 2 g of triblock copolymer P123 was first dissolved in 75 g of 1.6 M HCl, then a calculated amount of Ca(NO 3 ) 2 was added under stirring for 0.5 h. Thereafter, 4.25 g of TEOS was added under stirring at 40 °C. The resultant solution was stirred for 24 h at 40 °C, then transferred to a 100 ml autoclave and heated at 120 °C for another 24 h under static condition. Finally, the mixture was evaporated in a rotating evaporator under 55 °C and calcined at 550 °C in air for 6 h. The obtained sample was denoted as x Ca/SBA-15 where x represents the Ca/Si atomic ratio. For comparison, another Ca/SBA-15 sample was synthesized by an incipient impregnation (IM) procedure. First, SBA-15 was synthesized by the same procedure but without the introducing of Ca(NO 3 ) 2 . Then the SBA-15 sample calcined at 550 °C in air for 6 h was introduced into a calculated amount of Ca(NO 3 ) 2 aqueous solution. After 1 h, the resultant mixture was dried at 120 °C overnight and finally calcined at 550 °C in air for 6 h. The obtained sample was denoted as x Ca/SBA-15-IM where x represents the Ca/Si atomic ratio. 2.2 Sample characterization XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a RIGAKU D/MAX 2550/PC diffractometer using Cu K α1 radiation ( λ = 1.540 56 Å) at 40 kV and 100 mA, over a 2 θ range of 0.5–4.0° with a resolution of 0.02° at a scanning speed of 6°/min. The phases were identified using the power diffraction file (PDF) database (JCPDS, International Centre for Diffraction Data). FTIR spectra of the samples were recorded on a Nicolet MAGNAIR-560 spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm −1 with a resolution of 4 cm −1 . A standard KBr technique was used for the sample preparation. Raman spectra were acquired with a 325 nm line of a He–Cd laser (LabRAM, HR-800) with a resolution of 2 cm −1 at room temperature. The incident laser power at the sample was 2 mW. The morphologies and dimensions of materials were observed by SEM (HITACHI S-4700) and TEM (JEOL-2020F) using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The structures of the modified supports were measured by N 2 adsorption at 196 °C using an OMNISORP 100CX system (Coulter Co., USA). All samples were pretreated at 250 °C for 2 h in high vacuum. Pore size distribution, pore volume and its surface area were calculated on the isotherm of adsorption by a Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method. CO 2 -TPD was used to determine the basic strength and basicity of the samples. About 0.05 g of activated catalyst was filled in a silica tube (ca. 4 mm i.d.), treated at 550 °C for 1 h in Ar (20 ml/min), and CO 2 was then introduced for 1 h at room temperature. After purging with Ar for 1 h to remove CO 2 in the gas phase, the sample was heated from room temperature to 800 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min and the desorbed CO 2 was detected with a mass analyzer (Dymaxion Mass Spectrometer, AMETEK, the mass signal at m / z 44 was used to determine the amount of desorbed CO 2 ). 2.3 Transesterification reaction All experiments were performed in a 100 ml autoclave. It was charged with 10 g of sunflower oil (other oils as well), 10 g of anhydrous methanol (stoichiometrically 1:27), and 0.5 g of catalyst (5 wt.% of oil). The solid–oil–methanol mixture was heated to 200 °C under magnetic agitation. After a transesterification reaction time of 8 h, the mixture was filtered to remove the catalyst and the residual methanol was separated from the upper liquid phase (the lower phase is glycerin) via rotary evaporation. After that, the reaction products were washed three times with distilled water for removal of the formed glycerin. Products were analyzed by reserved-phase high performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC, Agilent 1100 Series) with a C18 Hypersil BDS column (150 mm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm particle size) using UV/visible detection at 210 nm [12,45] . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of Ca/SBA-15 samples Fig. 1 shows the small-angle XRD (SAXRD) patterns of SBA-15, of Ca/SBA-15 samples with Ca/Si atomic ratio varied from 0.1 to 0.5 and of 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample. All the Ca/SBA-15 samples showed the optimal ordering of the 2D-hexagonal P 6 mm structure [27] , indicating that a good preservation of the ordered mesoporous of SBA-15 silica can be achieved even at the Ca/Si ratio of 0.5 with one-pot synthesis method. But the intensity of all reflections decreased with the increased Ca content, which was probably caused by the decreasing scatter contrast between pore walls and pore space with the introduction of metal oxides [42] . It is worth noting that the SAXRD intensity of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 was much stronger than that of 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM, indicating that the ordered mesopores of SBA-15 silica are more easily to be preserved with one-pot synthesis procedure rather than incipient impregnation procedure. The N 2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of SBA-15, Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM samples are presented in Fig. 2 . The isotherms of all the Ca/SBA-15 samples were of type IV with an H1 hysteresis loop, very similar to that of SBA-15. This gives very strong evidence that pure silica SBA-15 and all Ca/SBA-15 and Ca/SBA-15-IM samples have ordered mesoporous structures [46] . The position of the inflections slightly shifted toward smaller p / p 0 values, and the amount of adsorbed N 2 decreased, which was due to the loading of calcium in SBA-15. As shown in Table 1 , both the surface area and the pore volume decreased gradually with the increasing amount of calcium in the samples. The surface area and the pore volume of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 are also larger than that of 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM. The long-range channel ordering can also be characterized by TEM technique. Fig. 3 illustrates the representative TEM images of SBA-15, 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM samples. The meso-structure was preserved in both 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM samples, consistent with the results of XRD and N 2 adsorption. The surfaces of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 are much like those of SBA-15, indicating the well distribution of calcium on the support SBA-15. Nevertheless, the surfaces of 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM seemed like to be covered by clouds which were caused by the overloading of calcium. This phenomenon suggests that one-pot synthesis of Ca-containing SBA-15 is much better than incipient impregnation method, at least in view of gaining a well dispersed material. The morphology and surface properties of Ca/SBA-15 materials were also characterized by SEM and SEM-EDS. As seen in Fig. 4 , 0.3Ca/SBA-15 was in better orientation than 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM, supporting our results of XRD, N 2 adsorption and TEM. In the SEM-EDS results, the surface Ca/Si ratio of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 is 0.27, lower than that of 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM which is 0.30. This can be explained by the good dispersion of calcium in both the surface and bulk of 0.3Ca/SBA-15. However, it is important to point out that there was still a large amount of Cl − ion (Cl/Ca atomic ratio = 0.33) detected on the surface of 0.3Ca/SBA-15. These Cl − ions were introduced by the using of HCl as an acidic source, and would probably lead to the formation of CaCl 2 after calcinations. The TG-DTA curves of SBA-15, 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM samples are shown in Fig. 5 . In the scan of SBA-15, the weight losses were concentrated in the range of 130–240 °C, and could be assigned to the decomposition of P123. The TG curve of the investigated 0.3Ca/SBA-15 sample was concentrated in two ranges (50–120 °C, 360–590 °C). The peak around 100 °C was assigned to the loss of physical adsorbed H 2 O, while the other two peaks at 420 and 460 °C could be attributed to the decomposition of Ca(NO 3 ) 2 . Interestingly, the DTG curve of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 showed several maxima at 250–450 °C which were not found in the scans of SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM, indicating that Ca/SBA-15 samples prepared by one-pot synthesis procedure requires lower temperature for the decomposition of Ca(NO 3 ) 2 . Infrared spectra were used to characterize the surface property of materials [47] . Fig. 6 shows the FTIR spectra of SBA-15 and Ca/SBA-15 materials calcined at 550 °C. The broad transmission band at approximately 3420 cm −1 could be attributed to the OH stretching vibration, while the one near 1630 cm −1 was associated with the bending mode of OH groups of physically adsorbed water [48] . It is noteworthy that the peaks at 1498 and 1438 cm −1 that corresponded to CO 3 2− symmetric stretching vibration band [49] were detected in the 0.4–0.5Ca/SBA-15 samples, while they were absent in the samples with the Ca/Si ratio of lower than 0.3. The increased intensity of both OH − and CO 3 2− groups indicates the enhanced basic strength with the increased Ca loading amount in Ca/SBA-15 samples [49] . A weak but sharp peak developed at 1384 cm −1 in the spectrum of 0.1Ca/SBA-15 and 0.2Ca/SBA-15 sample, which could be designated to the vibration of N–O of nitrate [50] . This was probably caused by the incomplete decomposition of Ca(NO 3 ) 2 . The band in the range of 1050–1100 cm −1 is assigned to vibration of Si–O bond [51,52] , and the peak in the samples is somewhat red-shifted as the amount of added Ca increases, which indicates the interaction between calcium and silicon. 3.2 Basic properties of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM samples CO 2 -TPD can be used to determine the basic strength and basicity of materials. In principle, the higher the CO 2 desorption temperature and the desorption rate are, the stronger basicity and basic strength the material has [40–42] . The CO 2 -TPD profiles of SBA-15, 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM samples are displayed in Fig. 7 . Only one CO 2 desorption peak at 120 °C was found in the SBA-15 sample, indicating that SBA-15 sample has only weak basic sites, which corresponding to the interaction of CO 2 with SiO 2 species [42] . With the loading of Ca, both the 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample showed stronger basic properties than SBA-15, but they were very different in the form of basic sites. There were new CO 2 desorption peaks at 220 °C in the profiles of both the 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and the 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample. These medium basic sites were probably caused by the adsorption of CO 2 on the surface of CaSiO 3 species [53,54] . It is worth noting that another peak in the range of 500–800 °C was detected in the 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample. This new peak is assigned to strong basic sites; it can be explained by the adsorption of CO 2 on the surface of isolated CaO species which is a super base [42] . Interestingly, there were no strong basic sites in the 0.3Ca/SBA-15 sample. This can be explained by the fact that there were only SiO 2 and CaSiO 3 species in the 0.3Ca/SBA-15 sample. It is well-known that CaO is a strong/super base, while CaSiO 3 is a salt with medium basic sites; thus the 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM samples appeared with different CO 2 adsorption properties. Accordingly, a schematic diagram of basic sites formation on SBA-15 by the two different methods was proposed ( Scheme 1 ). In the one-pot synthesis procedure, Ca 2+ was well dispersed in the silica framework before calcination, noting that there are many Si–OH groups on the surface of silica framework. After being activated at 550 °C, the well dispersed Ca 2+ easily reacted with silica species to form CaSiO 3 species though a certain amount of CaCl 2 was also formed. In the impregnation procedure, however, CaSiO 3 are much harder to be formed not only due to the loss of surface Si–OH groups at the first step calcinations, but also to the lower dispersion degree of Ca 2+ on the silica framework. The basic strengths of different samples were summarized in Table 2 . The amount of total basic sites of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 is 78.6 μmol/g, slightly less than that of 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM (91.4 μmol/g). This shortage of total basic sites was mainly due to the 29.0 μmol/g strong basic sites in the 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample. However, the amount of medium basic sites (220 °C) of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 reached 52.8 μmol/g, more than that of 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM (38.4 μmol/g). With the increasing loading of calcium, the amount of medium basic sites (220 °C) of x Ca/SBA-15 samples increased dramatically, and reached 88.1 μmol/g in the 0.5Ca/SBA-15 sample. There were, however, only a small number of strong basic sites in all these samples. This was probably caused by the preferred formation of CaSiO 3 species rather than CaO species due to the good dispersion of calcium on silica skeleton by one-pot synthesis method. 3.3 Influence of Ca/Si ratio on the transesterification reaction Table 3 also displays the catalytic activity of Ca/SBA-15 catalysts in the transesterification reaction. The reaction was carried out under the conditions mentioned in Section 2.3 . Pure SBA-15 only showed a very weak catalytic activity on the transesterification reaction, similar to the results for the condition of no catalyst. The biodiesel yields were basically related to the basic property of Ca/SBA-15 catalyst. As the Ca/Si ratio increased from 0.1 to 0.5, biodiesel yield increased until reaching its maxima of 99.1%. It is worth noting that 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM sample showed a better catalytic activity than that of 0.3 Ca/SBA-15 which was probably due to its higher basicity. 3.4 Influence of reaction temperature on the transesterification reaction The influence of reaction temperature on the transesterification reaction of sunflower oil was also studied. As shown in Fig. 8 , all the catalysts showed a very low activity at 60 °C. With a higher reaction temperature, the catalytic activity of all catalysts increased. A 99.1% biodiesel yield was achieved on the 0.5Ca/SBA-15 catalyst at 200 °C. Further increase in the reaction temperature would cause more energy use, so the reaction temperature was set to 200 °C in this study. 3.5 Influence of water and FFAs content on the transesterification reaction Generally, water and FFAs contained in the oils would inhibit the transesterification activity of the basic catalysts because they are sensitive to moisture and acids. Therefore, the durability of a catalyst in a water and FFA containing reaction system is somewhat important. In this study, the reaction rate was measured in the presence of water and FFAs (palmitic acid) by using 0.5Ca/SBA-15 as a catalyst. As seen from Fig. 9 , the catalytic activity was not affected by a water amount of lower than 5%. And 76% of biodiesel yield still can be achieved when 10% of water was added to the sunflower oil. Noting that a water content of lower than 5% can be easily obtained in an industrial process, the 0.5Ca/SBA-15 catalyst is thus suitable for transesterification reaction. It can also be seen that a certain amount of FFA (3%) did not affect the catalytic activity of 0.5Ca/SBA-15, though further increase of FFA content would decrease the catalytic activity. Especially when 10% of FFA was added, the catalytic activity dramatically decreased to as low as 10%. Therefore, if the oils contain a large amount of FFAs, an esterification step for FFAs will still be needed for this catalytic system. 3.6 Deactivation and regeneration of catalysts The catalysts were simply treated by separating; the remainders were washed thoroughly with methanol, and dried in an oven. Up to five cycles of different catalysts were performed on the transesterification of sunflower oil. As shown in Fig. 10 , no deactivation was found on the one-pot synthesized Ca/SBA-15 catalyst, indicating that Ca/SBA-15 catalysts were very stable in the tested cycles, while a dramatic decrease of catalytic activity was found on the 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM catalyst. As mentioned above, calcium species can more easily to form CaO in 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM while CaSiO 3 can more easily be formed in 0.3Ca/SBA-15. Thus, the interaction between calcium species and SBA-15 support in 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM catalyst was not as strong as in the 0.3Ca/SBA-15 sample. Although 0.3Ca/SBA-15-IM catalyst showed a better activity in transesterification of sunflower oil in the first run, it quickly deactivated in the second run. This indicates that Ca/SBA-15 catalyst prepared by one-pot synthesis method had a better stability; this result was caused by the better distribution of calcium species and enhanced interaction of calcium species with silica walls. One thing to be noted here is that the Ca/SBA-15 catalyst showed a much lower catalytic activity than the values for pure CaO reported in many research papers [23–26] . This may be explained by the better solubility of CaO in methanol and/or glycerol compared with CaSiO 3 . Thus, the homogeneous system contributed to activity more than the heterogeneous system in the transesterification reaction when using CaO as a catalyst [25] , which of course faces the leaching problem. CaO can easily be transformed into Ca(OH) 2 and CaCO 3 when exposed in air, as well as Ca(OCH 3 ) 2 and calcium diglyceroxide in the transesterification reaction system [26] . The instability of CaO restricts its applications in biodiesel production. In the practical application point of view, Ca/SBA-15 catalyst is better than CaO and than supported CaO prepared by impregnated method. For the transesterification reaction, it is important to find a more stable catalyst rather than a more active catalyst. 3.7 Transesterification of different vegetable oils The behaviors of 0.3Ca/SBA-15 and 0.5Ca/SBA-15 catalysts in transesterification of different vegetable oils are shown in Fig. 11 . Slight differences were observed as a function of the nature of the vegetable oil. Soybean oil was found to be the most active in the studied vegetable oils. 4 Conclusions Ca/SBA-15 samples were prepared by a convenient one-pot synthesis method. The mesoporous structure of SBA-15 was well preserved with Ca/Si ratio up to 0.5. Compared with Ca/SBA-15 sample prepared by impregnation method, the Ca/SBA-15 showed not only a better calcium species distribution, but also higher BET surface area and larger medium basic strength. Moreover, Ca/SBA-15 prepared by one-pot synthesis method requires less material and energy costs. When used in the transesterification reaction of sunflower oil with methanol, a biodiesel yield of as high as 99.1% was achieved on the 0.5Ca/SBA-15 catalyst calcined at 550 °C at a reaction temperature of 200 °C for 8 h. At the meantime, no deactivation was found after five cycles on Ca/SBA-15 sample prepared by one-pot synthesis method in the transesterification reaction. This showed a much better stability than that of the sample prepared by a conventional impregnation method. Besides, a water content of up to 5% and/or a free fatty acids (FFAs) content of 3% did not affect the catalytic activity of Ca/SBA-15 catalyst in the transesterification reaction, indicating that Ca/SBA-15 catalyst prepared by one-pot synthesis method will be a promising heterogeneous catalyst for biodiesel production. wLLAnK8V.title: Biodiesel production from transesterification by using KF/Sm2O3 as a catalyst
wLLAnK8V.abstract: Biodiesel production from transesterification of rapeseed oil using KF/Sm2O3 as a solid-base catalyst was studied. The production was analyzed by gas chromotography, and the catalyst was characterized by CO2-TPD, XRD, and Raman spectroscopy. When at the calcination temperature of 873 K, KF loading amount of 15%, methanol/oil molar ratio of 12:1, catalyst amount of 3%, reaction temperature of 338 K, and reaction time of 1 h, the FAME yield reached 95.1%.

et89Hhv6.title: Palladium-catalyzed decarboxylation of higher aliphatic esters: Towards a new protocol to the second generation biodiesel production

VdoaRQpJ.title: Room temperature transesterification of soybean oil to biodiesel catalyzed by rod-like CaxSiOx+2 solid base
VdoaRQpJ.abstract: Rod-like Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts were synthesized by using one-pot hydrothermal method. Catalysts calcined at 550 °C were used in the transesterification reaction of soybean oil with methanol. Under methanol reflux condition, FAME yields of 82% and 95% were achieved on Ca 4 SiO 6 in a reaction time of 1 and 2 h, separately. Also, the FAME yields on different Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts were correlated with their basic properties. Besides, a FAME yield of ca. 80% can be achieved under room temperature over Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst. Graphical abstract Research highlights ► Rod-like Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts were synthesized by using one-pot hydrothermal method. ► Under methanol reflux, a FAME yield of 95% was achieved on Ca 4 SiO 6 in 2 h. ► A FAME yield of ca. 80% can be achieved under room temperature on Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst. Keywords CO 2 -TPD Ca 3 SiO 5 Solid base Biodiesel Transesterification 1 Introduction Alternative renewable fuels have attracted considerable attentions recent years since traditional fossil fuels will be exhausted shortly. Biodiesel produced from vegetable oils, such as rapeseed, soybean and palm oil is one of the most promising forms of renewable energy. First generation of biodiesel (FGB) is usually produced via transesterification of vegetable oils with methanol/ethanol catalyzed by acid, base or enzyme [1,2] . Non catalytic supercritical fluid (SCF) of methanol/ethanol conditions is also used in the production of FGB [3,4] . These products were defined as fatty acid methyl/ethyl esters (FAME/FAEE). Second generation of biodiesel (SGB), produced via hydrodeoxygenation approach, has attracted some interest recently because it has the same components as diesel fuel [5] . During all these processes, acid and enzyme catalyzed transesterification usually required long reaction time while the SGB process required high reaction temperature. Thus, base catalyzed transesterification is still the most attractive process to date. Homogeneous basic catalysts such as sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide are commercially used for the transesterification reaction  [6] . Although they have certain advantages including high activity and mild reaction conditions, steps of catalysts removal and biodiesel separation and purification will produce a large amount of waste water. Heterogeneous basic catalysts have been widely investigated in the last decade in order to resolve the problems with homogeneous basic catalysts [7–12] . These catalysts include alkali and alkali earth metal oxides [7,8] , rare earth metal oxides [9] , hydrotalcites [10] , zeolites [11] and resins [12] . Among all these heterogeneous bases, CaO is the most attractive one not only because of its high activity but also the low cost of catalyst preparation [13–18] . However, Granados et al. found that CaO is soluble in methanol and larger amount of leached species was observed when glycerol is present [15] . Thus, pure CaO or supported CaO seems not adaptable for industrial applications. Recently, some catalysts have been investigated to enhance the stability of CaO, including MgO supported on CaO [19] , CaO–ZnO mixed oxide [20] and CaO–ZrO 2 mixed oxide [21] . Previous work has found that better calcium species distribution could be achieved on Ca/SBA-15 catalyst by using a one-pot hydrothermal method compared with traditional impregnation method [22] . Here, we present the one-pot hydrothermal method to prepare rod-like Ca x SiO x + 2 mixed oxide catalysts. The physicochemical properties of the prepared catalysts were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), N 2 adsorption, and CO 2 -temperature-programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) techniques. The catalytic activity of these catalysts was tested by the transesterification of soybean oil with methanol under methanol reflux or room temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts with Ca/Si molar ratio of 1, 2, 3 and 4 were synthesized according to standard literature procedures [23,24] . In a typical synthesis, 2 g of triblock copolymer P123 was first dissolved in 75 g of 1.6 M HCl, then a calculated amount of Ca(NO 3 ) 2 was added under stirring for 0.5 h. Thereafter, 4.25 g of TEOS was added under stirring at 40 °C. The resultant solution was stirred for 24 h at 40 °C, then transferred to a 100 ml autoclave and heated at 120 °C for another 24 h under static condition. Finally, the mixture was evaporated in a rotating evaporator under 55 °C. As synthesized catalysts were then kept in a vacuum dryer. Before transesterification reaction, catalysts were calcined at 550 °C in air for 6 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization XRD patterns of the samples were recorded on a RIGAKU D/MAX 2550/PC diffractometer using Cu K α1 radiation ( λ = 1.540 56 Å) at 40 kV and 100 mA, over a 2 θ range of 10–80° with a resolution of 0.02° at a scanning speed of 6° min − 1 . The morphologies and dimensions of materials were observed by TEM (JEOL-2020 F) using an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The structures of the modified catalysts were measured by N 2 adsorption at 196 °C on a Micromeritics ASAP 3020 M and Tristar system. All samples were pretreated at 250 °C for 2 h in high vacuum. Pore size distribution, pore volume and its surface area were calculated on the isotherm of adsorption by a Barrett–Joyner–Halenda method. CO 2 -TPD was used to determine the basic strength and basicity of the samples. About 0.05 g of activated catalyst was filled in a silica tube (ca. 4 mm i.d.), treated at 550 °C for 1 h in Ar (20 ml min − 1 ), and CO 2 was then introduced for 1 h at room temperature. After purging with Ar for 1 h to remove CO 2 in the gas phase, the sample was heated from room temperature to 800 °C with a ramp of 10 °C·min − 1 and the desorbed CO 2 was detected with a mass analyzer (Dymaxion Mass Spectrometer, AMETEK, the mass signal at m / z 44 was used to determine the amount of desorbed CO 2 ). 2.3 Transesterification reaction All experiments were performed in a 50 ml round bottom flask. It was charged with 10 g of soybean oil (acidity, 0.16 mg KOH/g oil), 5 g of anhydrous methanol (methanol/oil molar ratio 13:1), and 0.5 g of catalyst (5% wt. of oil). The solid–oil–methanol mixture was heated to 65 °C under magnetic agitation. Intermediate and final biodiesel products consisted of fatty acid methyl esters (FAME), monoglycerides, diglycerides and triglycerides. They were analyzed by reversed-phase high performance liquid chromatography (RP-HPLC, Agilent 1100 Series) with a C18 Hypersil BDS column (150 mm × 4.6 mm, 5 μm particle size) using UV/Visible detection at 210 nm [25,26] . Leaching tests were performed in the same procedure of transesterification reaction by detecting the calcium concentration in methanol phase using inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, IRIS Intrepid II XSP, Thermo Electron Co.). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts calcined at 550 °C. Mainly CaSiO 3 and Ca 2 SiO 4 phase were detected on CaSiO 3 and Ca 2 SiO 4 catalyst respectively, indicating that calcium silicate can be easily formed even at low calcination temperature by using this hydrothermal approach [27,28] . When the Ca/Si molar ratio increased to 3, almost pure Ca 3 SiO 5 phase was formed on Ca 3 SiO 5 catalyst [29–31] . It is worth to note that the main phase formed in Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst was Ca 3 SiO 5 with a trace amount of CaO. This suggested that an excess amount of calcium would lead to the incomplete reaction between calcium and silicate species. The textual properties of Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts were shown in Table S1 . The BET surface area of CaSiO 3 was as high as 144 m 2 ·g − 1 . However, when Ca/Si molar ratio increased, the BET surface areas of Ca 2 SiO 4 , Ca 3 SiO 5 and Ca 4 SiO 6 decreased drastically. The BET surface areas of Ca 2 SiO 4 , Ca 3 SiO 5 and Ca 4 SiO 6 were 13.7, 10.4 and 10.6 respectively. The N 2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts were also shown in Fig. S1 . Only the isotherm of CaSiO 3 sample was of type IV with an H1 hysteresis loop, indicating that the ordered mesoporous structure can be only preserved on CaSiO 3 sample [22] . Further increase in the Ca/Si molar ratio would cause structure destruction. The morphologies of Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts were characterized by using TEM technique, results are shown in Fig. 2 . The meso-structure was preserved in CaSiO 3 . However, unequal particle sizes were observed on the Ca 2 SiO 4 sample. These results were consistent with the N 2 adsorption results. When Ca/Si molar ratio increased to 3, Ca 3 SiO 5 sample were mainly in rod-like morphology. Interestingly, even longer rods with mean length of 1.1 μm were achieved on the Ca 4 SiO 6 sample. 3.2 Basic properties of Ca x SiO x + 2 samples calcined at 550 °C The basic properties including basic strength and basicity of a material are generally correlated with the CO 2 desorption temperature and desorption rate, which can be determined by CO 2 -TPD technique [10,32] . Fig. 3 displays the CO 2 -TPD profiles of Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts calcined at 550 °C. All samples exhibited only one CO 2 desorption peak at 620 °C which could be assigned to strong basic sites. The basic strength did not affected by the loading amount of calcium. However, with the increase of Ca/Si molar ratio, the amount of basic sites of Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts drastically increased till reach their maxima on Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst. This phenomenon indicates that the basic sites were mainly generated on calcium species. 3.3 Transesterification reaction on Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts Fig. 4 displays the transesterification reaction on different Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts under methanol reflux as a function of reaction time. As can be seen, only a FAME yield of 10% was achieved on CaSiO 3 even the reaction time was extended to 5 h. The FAME yields increased with the increasing Ca/Si molar ratio, and reached their maxima on Ca 4 SiO 6 . It is worth to note that Ca 3 SiO 5 and Ca 4 SiO 6 catalysts showed different pathways in the transesterification reaction. Although a FAME yield of 99% could be achieved on Ca 3 SiO 5 in 5 h, it seems that this catalyst needs to be activated in the first 2 h, at which time FAME yield only reached 24%. However, the FAME yields achieved on Ca 4 SiO 6 were 82% in 1 h and 95% in 2 h. And no activation step was needed for Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst (or the catalyst was activated quickly in this reaction system). Recently, leaching problems of solid base catalysts have been raised by many authors [33] . They stated that some of the solid base catalysts actually played homogeneous roles in the transesterification reaction while some were mixed homogeneous and heterogeneous. Thus, the reaction mechanism of the Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts were further studied by leaching test. As shown in Fig. S2 , calcium concentrations were only 0.07 and 0.09 mg ml − 1 in a reaction time of 1 and 2 h on Ca 3 SiO 5 catalyst. While, a calcium concentration of as high as 0.3 mg ml − 1 was found in 5 h. Unlike Ca 3 SiO 5 , a much higher calcium concentration (0.18 mg ml − 1 ) was detected in 1 h on Ca 4 SiO 6 , indicating that leaching of calcium species occurred easier on Ca 4 SiO 6 than Ca 3 SiO 5 . These results can be correlated with the catalytic activity, which is that the higher leaching amount of calcium leads to higher FAME yield. Thus, we can conclude that Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts played mainly homogeneous role in this system. 3.4 Transesterification reaction on Ca x SiO x + 2 catalysts at room temperature The catalytic activities of Ca 3 SiO 5 and Ca 4 SiO 6 catalysts were further investigated at room temperature, results are shown in Fig. 5 . Same trends were found on these two catalysts. As expected, longer reaction time was needed for both catalysts to complete the transesterification reaction. However, a FAME yield of ca. 80% can still be achieved on Ca 4 SiO 6 in 10 h. For comparison, reaction was also carried out at room temperature by using NaOH as a homogeneous catalyst. Not surprisingly, higher FAME yields can be achieved when using NaOH as a catalyst compared with Ca 4 SiO 6 . This is mainly due to the faster reaction rate of homogeneous reactions than heterogeneous ones. However, the catalytic activity of Ca 4 SiO 6 was not much lower than NaOH which made Ca 4 SiO 6 a promising catalyst for industrial applications. 3.5 Deactivation and regeneration of catalysts The Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst was simply treated by separating, washing thoroughly with methanol, and drying in an oven. No deactivation was found on the catalyst in the first 3 runs ( Table S2 ). However, FAME yields drastically decreased to 78.3% and 46.8% in the fourth and fifth run respectively. This was probably caused by the leaching problem of calcium species which led to the loss of calcium sites in Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst. 4 Conclusions Rod-like Ca x SiO x + 2 solid base catalysts were prepared by hydrothermal method. The catalysts were successively used in the biodiesel production via transesterification reaction of soybean oil with methanol. Under the optimum reaction conditions, FAME yield of up to 95% was achieved on the Ca 4 SiO 6 catalyst calcined at 550 °C. u39Hc8mX.title: Carbon nanofibers supported molybdenum carbide catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation of vegetable oils
u39Hc8mX.abstract: Carbon nanofiber-supported molybdenum carbide catalysts (Mo 2C/CNF) with different loadings were prepared by the carbothermal hydrogen reduction method. Characterizations with Raman, XRD, N2-TGA, SEM, TEM and HAADF-STEM confirmed that Mo2C nanoparticles were successfully supported on the carbon nanofibers. The optimal reaction conditions with model compounds on Mo2C/CNF had a conversion of 98.03% and yield of 95.26%. It is interesting to note that a low evaporation rate positions the Mo2C nanoparticles on the outside of the CNF due to the capillary effect and the Mo2C nanoparticles on the outside of the CNFs showed high catalytic activity compared to ones on the inside of the CNFs. The Mo2C/CNF catalyst was recycled 5 times without any apparent loss of catalytic activity. Catalytic performances of Mo2C/CNF, Mo 2C/AC (activated carbon) and Mo2C/CNT (multi-walled carbon nanotubes) were examined using methyl palmitate and maize oil. The results showed that molybdenum carbide could be a potential substitute for noble metals in transformation of vegetable oils. © 2013 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

XXgfebPl.title: Biodiesel production from transesterification of rapeseed oil using KF/Eu2O3 as a catalyst
XXgfebPl.abstract: The transesterification of rapeseed oil with methanol was carried out using a novel KF-loaded Eu2O3 catalyst. It was found that the catalyst with 15 wt % loaded KF and calcined at 873 K showed the optimum activity. X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FTIR), CO2-temperature-programmed desorption (TPD), and the Hammett titration method were employed for the catalyst characterization. The results showed that the activity of the catalysts was related with their basicity. The influence of various reaction variables on the conversion was also discussed. The mechanism for the formation of basic sites and the phase change of the KF-loaded Eu2O3 catalyst with different calcination temperatures is proposed. © 2008 American Chemical Society.

kXGeHEj9.title: Carbon-supported molybdenum carbide catalysts for the conversion of vegetable oils.
kXGeHEj9.abstract: Ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC)-supported molybdenum carbide catalysts were successfully prepared in one pot using a solvent-evaporation-induced self-assembly strategy accompanied by a carbothermal hydrogen reduction reaction. Characterization with nitrogen sorption, small-angle XRD, and TEM confirmed that the obtained materials had high surface areas, large pore volumes, ordered mesoporous structures, narrow pore size distributions, and uniform dispersions of molybdenum carbide particles. With nitrogen replaced by hydrogen in the carbothermal reduction reaction, the formation temperature of molybdenum carbide could be reduced by more than 100 °C. By changing the amount of molybdenum precursor added from less than 2 % to more than 5 %, molybdenum carbide structures could be easily regulated from Mo(2) C to MoC. The catalytic performance of OMC-supported molybdenum carbide catalysts was evaluated by hydrodeoxygenation of vegetable oils. Compared with Mo(2)C, MoC exhibited high product selectivity and excellent resistance to leaching in the conversion of vegetable oils into diesel-like hydrocarbons.

9l4xWdo4.title: Effect of addition of Sm2O3 on property of CuO-��-Al2O3 catalyst
9l4xWdo4.abstract: Effect of the addition of Sm2O3 on CuO-��-Al2O3 catalyst for CO oxidation reaction was investigated. The result shows that the right amount of Sm2O3 can promote the adsorption of the surface oxygen and recovery of CuO-��-Al2O3 catalyst. Sm2O3 plays an important role in change of ��-Al2O3 phase into ��-Al2O3 phase. In addition, the right amount of Sm2O3(5%) can improve the oxidation activity of the CuO-��-Al2O3 catalyst. Whereas an excess of Sm2O3(10%) makes the CuO crystal in CuO-��-Al2O3 catalyst become bigger and restrain the oxidation activity of the CuO-��-Al2O3 catalyst.

vth5nddv.title: A structural study of the series CexZrl-xO2 mixed oxides
vth5nddv.abstract: The CexZrl-xO2 (x=0∼1.0) mixed oxides have been prepared by sol-gel method, and their crystal structure investigated by Rietveld analysis. The phase compositions and cell parameters depend on the CeO2 content. Tetragonal phase is observed in Ce0.1Zr0.9O2 and Ce0.2Zr0.8O2 samples, while cubic phase is observed in the compositional range 0.7≤×≤1. Therefore, both cubic and tetragonal phases have been found in the range 0.3≤×≤.6; the content of cubic phase increases with increasing x.

4W0L4bVs.title: Hydrodeoxygenation of Bio-Derived Phenol to Cyclohexane Fuel Catalyzed by Bifunctional Mesoporous Organic-Inorganic Hybrids.
4W0L4bVs.abstract: In this work, mesoporous silica materials SBA-15 functionalized with propyl/ phenyl-sulfonic acid group were synthesized and loaded with Pt to form bifunctional catalysts. SAXRD, WAXRD, N adsorption-desorption, TEM techniques were used to characterize the above bifunctional catalysts. These bifunctional catalysts were applied to the reaction of hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of bio-derived phenol (PhOH) to produce cyclohexane fuel and showed very good catalytic performances. There were strong synergies between the metal sites and the acid sites on the bifunctional catalysts. This reaction of phenol HDO provides a model system for the catalytic upgrading of biomass-derived fuel.

U1q7LaXk.title: RETRACTED ARTICLE: Effect of Gd2O3 over Ni/SiO2 on syngas production via methane autothermal reforming
U1q7LaXk.abstract: GdO-promoted Ni/SiO catalysts exhibited higher activity and selectivity than Ni/SiO in methane autothermal reforming. The results of the temperature-programmed surface reaction of CH indicated that GdO might enhance anti-carbon deposition properties. The reactivity of surface carbons showed that the presence of GdO reduced the formation of inactive carbons on Ni/SiO. Raman results suggested that the order of graphitization of deposited carbon decreases with the addition of GdO.

TWTE81Ea.title: Effects of graphitization of carbon nanospheres on hydrodeoxygenation activity of molybdenum carbide
TWTE81Ea.abstract: Cellulose-derived carbon materials were prepared and employed as supports for molybdenum carbide catalysts, and their catalytic activity for hydrodeoxygenation of maize oil was tested in an autoclave under different reaction conditions. Carbon nanospheres, which can be simply synthesized via hydrothermal carbonization and whose morphology can be easily controlled, were employed as supports to study the relationship between the graphitization degree of carbon supports and the hydrodeoxygenation activity of supported molybdenum carbide catalysts. Ferric chloride was employed as a graphitization reagent to modify the surface properties of the carbon nanospheres. Graphitized carbon nanosphere materials with appropriate FeCl3 to carbon ratios (1–50%) showed outstanding properties to work as supports for Mo2C catalysts. Suitable reaction conditions for comparing these catalysts were found out by testing carbon nanosphere supported Mo2C catalysts with different loadings (5–40%) at several temperatures (513–553 K) and initial hydrogen pressures (2.0–3.0 MPa). The best conversion and hydrocarbon yield they reached were 91.1% and 88.3%, which were 21% and 31% higher than the results from the ungraphitized carbon nanosphere supported catalyst under the same conditions, respectively. Cellulose-derived carbon materials might be competitive with carbon nanotubes as catalyst supports in the field of hydrodeoxygenation and maybe in other areas.

rOo3KAw2.title: Hierarchical mesoporous ZSM-5 for the dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether
rOo3KAw2.abstract: Hierarchical mesoporous ZSM‐5 zeolites were synthesized using small organic cations of tetrapropylammonium and meso‐sized cationic polymers of dimethyldiallyl ammonium chloride acrylamide copolymer as templates.The zeolites were used for the dehydration of methanol to dimethyl ether(DME).Characterization results showed that the basic MFI‐type structure was still obtained after adding the cationic polymers,while their nitrogen isotherms exhibited a broad hysteresis loop at relative pressures higher than 0.4,which proved the presence of mesopores.The mesoporosity of the hierarchical mesoporous ZSM‐5 can be adjusted simply by adding different amounts of the cationic polymer.Catalytic tests showed that the hierarchical mesoporous HZSM‐5 zeolites exhibited better stability than conventional HZSM‐5 and excellent DME selectivity.The activity for methanol dehydration strongly depended on the textural property and acidity of the catalyst.
keywords: hierarchical mesopore hzsm‐5 zeolite surface acidity methanol dehydration dimethyl ether

OhQdrADl.title: Characteristics of the Decomposition of CO2 in a Dielectric Packed-Bed Plasma Reactor
OhQdrADl.abstract: The decomposition of CO in a dielectric packed-bed plasma reactor has been studied. It was found that the dielectric properties and morphology of packing dielectric pellets play important roles in the reaction due to their influence on the electron energy distribution in the plasma. The acid–base properties of the packing materials also affect the reaction through the chemisorption of CO on basic sites of the materials. Heterogeneous reactions on the solid surfaces of the dielectric materials also play a role in the reaction, which was also confirmed through the investigation of the influence of the discharge length on the reaction. The reverse reaction of CO decomposition, the oxidation of CO, was also investigated to further understand the role of dielectric materials in the plasma and their effect on plasma reactions. Both the decomposition of CO and the oxidation of CO in non-packed or dielectric packed reactors are first-ordered.

522EqyVY.title: Relationship between health behaviors and factors and brachial-ankle pulse wave velocity in middle-aged and elderly population
522EqyVY.abstract: Objective To explore the effect of cardiovascular health behaviors and factors on atherosclerosis in middle-aged and elderly population. Methods A total of 5440over 40-year old employees from Tangshan Kailuan Company were recruited by stratified random sampling and devided into non-atherosclerosis group [ brachial-ankle pulse wave velocity ( baPWV ) <1400cm / s ] or atherosclerosis group ( baPWV≥1400cm / s ) .Subjects with previous stroke , TIA , myocardial infarction were excluded. Multivariate Logistic regression analysis was used to analyze the effect of health behaviors ( including smoking , body mass index , physical activity and health diet ) and factors ( including total cholesterol , blood pressure and fasting plasma glucose ) on baPWV. Results In atherosclerosis group , the proportion of male and current smoking were higher , and physical activity was more common.The age , baPWV , body mass index , systolic blood pressure , diastolic blood pressure , total cholesterol , fasting blood glucose , low density lipoprotein and triglyceride in atherosclerosis group were significantly higher than those in non-atherosclerosis group , while high density lipoprotein was significantly lower ( all P<0.05 ) .With the increasing cardiovascular health behaviors and factors , the baPWV decreased , which was ( 1646.1±325.0 ),( 1620.8±317.3 ), ( 1586.4±360.0 ),( 1564.2±370.1 ),( 1528.7±376.8 ),( 1458.6±388.2 ),( 1393.4±360.9 ) and ( 1207.8± 212.6 ) cm / s respectively ; and the prevalence of atherosclerosis decreased , which was 84.5% , 77.3% , 68.6% , 65.0% , 57.8% , 45.6% , 35.7%and 13.0%respectively ( P<0.05 ) . After adjusting the age , sex , low density lipoprotein , triglyceride and high density lipoprotein , multivariate logistic regression analysis showed individuals withmore than 2of cardiovascular health behaviors and factors showed lower risk of atherosclerosis [ OR=0.601 ( 0.460-0.785 ), 0.536 ( 0.410-0.699 ), 0.398 ( 0.300-0.528 ), 0.248 ( 0.179-0.343 ), 0.161 ( 0.101-0.255 ) respectively ], comparing to those with 0or 1behavior or factor. Conclusion The ideal cardiovascular health behaviors and factors show inhibiting effects on atherosclerosis in middle-aged and elderly population.

WOojTUMR.title: Follow-up of the effects of treating aortic dissection:with China-made endovascular stent:analysis of 12 cases
WOojTUMR.abstract: Objective To evaluate the long-term results of China-made endovascular stent in treatment of aortic dissection.Methods 12 patients with Stanford type B aortic dissection,8 males and 4 females,aged 61.2,9 in the acute stage and 3 in the chronic stage,underwent endoluminal implantation of stent specialized for the patients covered with 100μm woven silk patch.The patients were followed up for 69.2 months(66～72 months).Results All operations were successful.No death and severe complication had been found.2 cases recurrence of new aortic dissection was discovered in the aorta distal to the stent in 2 cases.A false aneurysm occurred in the right femoral artery in one female case and needed an operation to repair.Conclusions Endovascular covered stent is safe and effective in treatment of aortic dissection with satisfactory long-term outcomes.

aDKUmAkf.title: Relationship between atrial fibrillation and blood pressure in males of Kailuan mine
aDKUmAkf.abstract: Objective To study the prevalence of atrial fibrillation (AF) and its relationship with blood pressure in males of Kailuan mine. Methods From June 2006 to October 2007, 101 510 staff members of Kailuan Co. Ltd participated in health examination and completed unified questionnaires. All participants underwent 12-lead electrocardiogram and physical examination. The prevalence of AF and its relationship with blood pressure were calculated and analysed by Logistic regression analysis. Results A total of 81 061 in 81 103 male participants accomplished electrocardiogram. Three hundred and ninety-eight were diagnosed with AF (37 valvular AF and 361 non-valvular AF) and the prevalence of AF was 0.49%. The prevalence of non-valvular AF in hypertensive population was significantly higher than that of the normotensives (0.54% vs 0.36%, P<0.01). The univariate Logistic regression analysis showed that the risks of AF in the population with systolic blood pressure (SBP) 120-<140 and ≥140 mm Hg were respectively 1.44 and 3.58 times that of SBP<120 mm Hg. The prevalence of AF in the population with pulse pressure (PP) 50-<60 and ≥60 mm Hg was respectively 1.55, 2.11 times that of PP<40 mm Hg. After the adjustment of all influence factors of AF, the hazard ration in the population with SBP≥140 mm Hg was 1.74 times that of SBP<120 mm Hg. Conclusions The prevalence of AF in hypertensive population is significantly higher than in normotensive. SBP is an independent risk factor for the males with AF. The prevalence of AF is not related with diastolic blood pressure or PP.

ZmaCiUbM.title: Progress of blood pressure and influence factors in prehypertensives
ZmaCiUbM.abstract: Objective To explore the relationship between blood pressure progression and risk factors in prehypertension populations.Methods A population-based cohort of 33 913 subjects with prehypertension diagnosed according to Guildlines for Prevention and Treatment of Hypertension in China 2005 in the health examination for the employees of Kailuan group were followed-up from 2006 to 2007.The population were followed up during the period of 2008 to 2009 again,in order to analysis the distribution of age and gender in different subtype of hypertension,to identify main determining risk factors promoting prehypertension to hypertension.Results During the 2-years follow-up period,8361 individuals developed into hypertension in all 25 474 cases with prehypertension,in which 1615 cases(20.77%)were isolated systolic hypertension(ISH),2879 cases(37.03%)were isolated diastolic hypertension(IDH),and 3281 cases(42.20%)were systolic and diastolic hypertension(SDH).A total of 7775 patients were divided into <40,40-<50,50-<60 and ≥60 years four groups by age.The percentage of ISH increased in older patients.The percentage of SDH increased with age,but decreased in ≥60 years group.The percentage of IDH increased in the <60 years group,especially in 40-<50 years group,and decreased to 16.0%(P<0.05)in the group aged ≥60 years.Multiple logistic regression showed that risk factors for ISH were age,fasting plasma glucose(FPG),low density lipoprotein-cholesterol(LDL-C),systolic blood pressure(SBP),body mass index(BMI)and cigarette.Risk factors for IDH were gender(male),age,triglyeride(TG),diastolic blood pressure(DBP),SBP,waist circumference(WC),BMI and alcohol.Gender(male),age,FPG,LDL-C,TG,DBP,SBP,WC,BMI,TC and alcohol were risk factors for SDH.Conclusion The percentage of established hypertension developed from prehypertension were 20.77%,37.03% and 42.20% in ISH,IDH and SDH respectively.Age,gender,WC,TC have significant impact on the development from prehypertension to hypertension.

i00V1iQa.title: Metabolic syndrome is associated with and predicted by resting heart rate: a cross-sectional and longitudinal study.
i00V1iQa.abstract: Although higher resting heart rate (RHR) has emerged as a predictor for lifespan, the underlying mechanisms remain obscure. The present study investigates whether a positive relationship exists between RHR and metabolic syndrome (MetS) and whether RHR predicts future MetS.A cohort of 89,860 participants were surveyed during 2006-2007 in Kailuan/Tangshan, China. MetS was diagnosed when a participant presented at least three of the following: abdominal adiposity, low high density lipoprotein-cholesterol, high triglycerides, hypertension or impaired fasting glucose. RHR was derived from ECG recordings and subjects were stratified based on RHR. Some participants without MetS at baseline were followed-up for 4 years.At baseline, 23,150 participants (25.76%) had MetS. There was a positive association between RHR and MetS. The OR of having MetS was 1.49 (95% CI 1.32 to 1.69) in subjects with RHR at 95-104 compared with those at 55-64 beats per minute (bpm) (reference), after adjusting for variables including age, sex, education, cigarette smoking, alcohol drinking, physical activities, body mass index, hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidaemia, inflammatory biomarkers and renal function. More importantly, when 43,725 individuals from the original study without MetS at baseline were followed-up, higher RHR was found to predict greater risk of MetS incidence. The OR of developing MetS 4 years later was 1.41 (95% CI 1.21 to 1.65) in subjects with RHR at 95-104 bpm compared with reference, after all adjustments.Our cross-sectional and longitudinal findings provide evidence that RHR is an independent risk factor for existing MetS and a powerful predictor for future incidence of MetS.
